In the longer run, though, it could harm U.S. interests by isolating the country from global trade flows. “The U.S. has overestimated its leverage over the world economy. It accounts for just 13% of world imports,” Richard Baldwin, a professor of international economics at the International Institute for Management Development in Lausanne, Switzerland, told me. That’s for the future, though. Right now, the best Japanese automakers can do, along with other sellers of goods and services to the United States, is hunker down, because a storm is coming.

title: TSMC’s big U.S. bet and China’s chip tool challenger
description: The inside story on the Asia tech trends that matter, from Nikkei Asia and the Financial Times March 27, 2025 16:54 JST Hello! This is Lauly, saying hi from the warm weather in Taipei. I can’t believe it’s already been weeks since I returned from Barcelona covering the annual Mobile World Congress, one of the biggest tech exhibitions in a year. As my colleague Annie Cheng Ting-Fang mentioned in her newsletter, we had to take cold showers for three nights at our hotel due to a plumbing issue, walked more than 10,000 steps at the expo and then had to endure subway disruptions for two straight days. And that was not all. I remember I was on my way back from the exhibition to the hotel when I was alerted that C.C. Wei, chairman and CEO of TSMC, the world’s biggest contract chipmaker, was going to announce a major investment at the White House. My jaw dropped and I texted Annie, and hers dropped as well. I jumped out of the train when it arrived at the station, quickly bought two baguettes (important, as that would be our only food for the night), and ran back to the hotel to start writing. Meanwhile, Annie left a media gathering for a Chinese smartphone maker and hurried back to join me. It had already been such a long day, but thanks to the help of our U.S. colleagues, we were able to cover TSMC’s $100 billion investment announcement . Back in Taiwan, we spent two weeks talking to more than a dozen chip industry people and analysts to try to understand what this bold bet on the U.S. would mean economically and politically. The announcement has become a political saga at home . I was amazed to see politicians from both ends of the spectrum all suddenly becoming linguists, translating and deciphering each word of President Donald Trump when he said the U.S. would still have a “big part” in the chip industry should any conflict break out in the Taiwan Strait. From social networks to political talk shows, TSMC dominated the public discourse for more than a week. And then there was GTC, the annual tech event hosted by Nvidia, the world’s biggest AI chip company. I went to lunch with an executive of an Nvidia supplier a day before he flew to San Francisco for the event. We chatted about TSMC’s investments in the U.S. and Nvidia’s rather volatile stock performance since the emergence of China’s DeepSeek. Like many in the Nvidia AI server supply chain, the executive assured me that the robust demand from cloud service providers persists and that all AI server suppliers are hoping Nvidia will allocate more orders to them. “Lauly, do you know why I need to attend this year’s GTC, why every high-ranking executive from all of the suppliers attend the GTC? It’s like participating in the Matsu Goddess Pilgrimage to get closer to Matsu,” he joked. “If you go and pray, you will get the chance to be blessed.” TSMC’s biggest bet Taiwan, which boasts the second-largest semiconductor industry in the world, has long taken a measure of comfort in its “Silicon Shield,” the concept that its crown jewel chip economy makes it too important for the U.S. not to defend it should China ever invade. But what if the shield is weakened ? That question has been growing over the years, and it took on even more urgency when TSMC Chairman and CEO C.C. Wei stood alongside U.S. President Donald Trump and announced plans to invest an additional $100 billion to build more plants in the country, write Nikkei Asia’s Cheng Ting-Fang and Lauly Li . TSMC’s planned investment in the U.S. has ballooned from an initial $12 billion in 2020 to $40 billion in 2022, then to $65 billion in 2024 and finally to $165 billion, more than 10 times its original commitment and its largest overseas investment ever. The Taiwanese contract chipmaking titan is even busier expanding capacity at home, too, but this cannot disguise the fact TSMC and Taiwan more broadly are facing unprecedented levels of pressure from the U.S. and China. “We don’t see the tides turning overnight,” a longtime chip equipment executive told Nikkei Asia. “But in five to 10 years, if U.S. investments fully materialize, they will certainly weaken Taiwan’s role as the world’s top hub for advanced chips. You can’t expect TSMC to replicate these costly facilities in two places.” The DeepSeek effect DeepSeek released an update to its open-source model V3 this week, which ranked highly on independent benchmarks for assessing the model’s performance. Once again, developers praised the small startup for sharing its secret sauce with the AI community for free, write the Financial Times’ Eleanor Olcott , Ryan McMorrow and Zijing Wu . The research lab is shaking up the global AI competition with its powerful and free open-source models. Its success has prompted some soul searching among local rivals that have poured money into model training without the same results. Moonshot, owner of the popular Kimi chatbot, has slashed its marketing budget to focus on model training. Meanwhile, Baichuan laid off its sales team devoted to selling to financial institutions in February, opting to double down on its health care focus. Investors in Zhipu are questioning why the startup is burning through so much cash. Last year, Zhipu, once considered Beijing’s favored large language model startup, made 300 million yuan in sales and 2 billion yuan in losses. It has pinned its hopes on an IPO to sustain its cash-intensive growth, but DeepSeek’s newfound popularity may complicate its path to a listing. The Beijing-based 01.ai stands out from the crowd, having fully embraced what it calls a “DeepSeek Age.” The Kai-Fu Lee-founded startup stopped pretraining LLMs in late 2024 and, in recent weeks, has pivoted to focus on selling tailored AI business solutions using DeepSeek’s models. An AI for an AI In Mandarin, there is a saying similar to “a taste of your own medicine” in English. As scammers around the world use artificial intelligence to ensnare victims, companies like Apate.ai are giving them a dose of this, using AI to counter the scams , Nikkei Asia’s Shaun Turton writes. The Australian startup uses AI bot to create “victims” to soak up scammers’ time and gather insights into their activities. Their Apate Voice product creates AI personas that field calls and engage with scammers whose tactics range from impersonating bank staff and merchants to pushing fraudulent investment schemes. The company also created Apate Text, which does the same thing for text exchanges. The global scam industry has boomed in recent years. A 2024 Global Anti-Scam Alliance report estimated people around the world lost $1.03 trillion in 2023, with only 4% of victims able to fully recover their money. Southeast Asian countries like Cambodia and Myanmar have emerged as hot spots for scam operations, which are also linked to human trafficking. In this environment, Apate.ai sees many opportunities for its product, which can handle tens of thousands of calls and is already being used in Australia, the U.K. and Singapore, with collaborations with governments, cryptocurrency exchanges and financial institutions. An alternative to ASML Shenzhen SiCarrier Technologies, a Chinese chipmaking tool maker linked to Huawei, has been quietly developing a wide range of equipment to replace tools made by ASML, Applied Materials and Lam Research as part of the national effort to unshackle the most painful supply chain choke point created by U.S. export controls, according to this scoop by Nikkei Asia’s Cheng Ting-Fang and Lauly Li . Founded in 2021 and backed by the Shenzhen government, the company has been developing machines involving lithography, chemical vapor deposition, measurement, physical vapor deposition, etching and atomic layer deposition, all fields that are currently dominated by companies from the Netherlands, U.S. and Japan, said multiple people familiar with the situation. SiCarrier has been working closely with Huawei’s growing team of specialists in chip production and chip equipment making, multiple sources with knowledge of the matter said. In a recent post on WeChat, SiCarrier said it will launch a wide range of chipmaking equipment machines during the SEMICON China industry fair this week, including a new atomic layer deposition (ALD) tool named Alishan, after a famous mountain in Taiwan. China leads the charge in vanadium batteries as Australia rushes to catch up Welcome to the Tech Latest podcast. Hosted by our tech coverage veterans, Katey Creel and Akito Tanaka, every Tuesday we deliver the hottest trends and news from the sector. In this episode, Katey speaks with Australia correspondent Shaun Turton about the rise of vanadium batteries in China and how they challenge Australia’s ambitions to become a renewable energy superpower. Find us on Apple Podcasts | Spotify | Amazon Music | Voicy | YouTube | YouTube Music Suggested reads 1. Nvidia’s China sales face threat from Beijing’s environmental curbs (FT) 2. Vietnam approves Starlink service in 5-year pilot plan (Nikkei Asia) 3. Malaysia to crack down on Nvidia chip flows under US pressure (FT) 4. Carmakers focus on hybrids as Thai EV market struggles (Nikkei Asia) 5. Samsung CEO Han Jong-hee dies of cardiac arrest (Nikkei Asia) 6. China is suffering its own ‘China shock’ (FT) 7. Trump administration hits China with slew of tech export controls (Nikkei Asia) 8. US investors in ByteDance explore TikTok deal to appease Donald Trump (FT) 9. Nissan incoming CEO Espinosa has ‘no taboos’ on partnerships (Nikkei Asia) 10. Japan is out of the chip race but still in the game (FT) For more great stories like this delivered to your inbox every week, sign up to our #techAsia newsletter. Current subscribers, click here to update your newsletters preferences.

title: Brazil’s Lula strengthens Asia ties, vows to fight Trump tariffs
description: Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva speaks to reporters in Tokyo on March 27, delivering a sharp critique of U.S. President Donald Trump's tariff policy. (Photo by Tamayo Muto) President defends multilateral trading system and hopes for Mercosur-Japan deal TAMAYO MUTO TAMAYO MUTO March 27, 2025 16:35 JST TOKYO — Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva launched a defense of free trade and multilateralism in Tokyo on Thursday, while threatening to hit back at U.S. President Donald Trump’s tariffs. “Multilateralism is significant,” Lula told reporters a day after he met Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba. “The country that once advocated free trade is now advocating protectionism,” he said, referring to the U.S. Nevertheless, Lula said his government is willing to respond in kind and “impose reciprocal tariffs” on the U.S. His remarks came hours after Trump announced a new 25% tariff on foreign-made cars , and days before the White House is expected to unveil a flurry of new tariffs on global trade partners on April 2, dubbed “liberation day.” In their meeting, Lula and Ishiba had emphasized a shared commitment to free trade and laid out the “Strategic and Global Partnership Action Plan Japan-Brazil” for the five years through 2030. The document states that “Japan and Brazil reaffirm their commitment to a free, open, fair, rules-based, nondiscriminatory and equitable multilateral trading system.” On Thursday, Lula said he “cannot understand” what Trump hopes to achieve by imposing the 25% tax on foreign cars, including those from Japan. “It is also a disadvantage for the U.S.,” he said. “It will cause inflation. … President Trump may not yet understand, but time will tell everything.” Trump this month also slapped 25% tariffs on imported steel and aluminum . Brazil is a key exporter of the metals and Lula said his government would appeal at the World Trade Organization. Some observers have noted that Brazil could also benefit from the U.S.-China trade war, to an extent, becoming an even more competitive supplier of agricultural commodities such as soybeans. After Trump hit China with two rounds of blanket additional 10% tariffs, Beijing responded earlier this month with 10-15% tariffs on a range of U.S. farm goods, including soybeans. Still, Lula said he is “concerned about increased tariffs in any industries” and lamented that a cold trade war between the U.S. and China “should not be allowed.” “Trade should be free,” he said. Brazil’s Lula and Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba hold a ceremony at the Akasaka Palace State Guest House in Tokyo on March 26.   © Reuters Lula, who will also serve as the rotating president of the Southern Common Market (Mercosur) from the latter half of this year, hopes to push that philosophy and tighten trade ties with Asia, with Japan in focus. “I will actively work to conclude an agreement between Mercosur and Japan, just like with the EU,” he said on Thursday. In December, the European Union and Mercosur signed a trade and cooperation pact after 25 years of negotiations. This is the only deal that Mercosur has with a major trading bloc, giving products from Europe an advantage over imports from Japan or the U.S. But Lula said he wants to launch negotiations with Japan during Brazil’s Mercosur presidency, although political considerations within Japan could make for an uphill battle. Likewise, Brazil is pushing Japan to restart beef imports, long frozen due to Tokyo’s cautious stance over safety, including concerns about bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE). “We will let Japan send a delegation to inspect production sites in Brazil as soon as possible,” Lula said. “We can provide beef with higher quality and cheaper prices than any other country. We hope to find a solution within this year.” After serving two earlier terms as president, from 2003 to the end of 2010, Lula was jailed over corruption allegations that he denies. The convictions were annulled by a court and he was allowed to run again in the 2022 election, when he scored a narrow victory over a man many critics consider the “Trump of the Tropics,” then-incumbent Jair Bolsonaro. This week, Brazil’s Supreme Court ruled that Bolsonaro should stand trial for alleged involvement in an attempted coup plot against Lula — an accusation the former president called “baseless.” “I hope the Supreme Court will work in the way it should,” Lula said when asked about the case. Since returning to lead his divided country in January 2023, the former factory worker turned leftist politician Lula has sought to position Brazil as a key voice of the “Global South” emerging nations, alongside BRICS partners such as China and India. At Thursday’s news conference, Lula insisted that Washington should not be calling the shots on global affairs. “The president of the U.S. is not the boss of the world,” he said. “He should make a decision after exchanging opinions with partner countries.”

title: Japan’s Fuji media mogul Hieda to quit as managing adviser
description: Fuji Media Holdings' executive Hisashi Hieda. Company's broadcast unit under fire for its handling of TV host scandal March 27, 2025 16:31 JST TOKYO (Kyodo) — Longtime Fuji Media Holdings executive Hisashi Hieda will step down from his role as managing adviser, the company said Thursday, with its broadcasting unit under fire for its handling of a sexual misconduct scandal involving former TV host Masahiro Nakai. Hieda also left his role as executive managing adviser of the scandal-hit Fuji Television Network as of Thursday.

title: Trump tariffs prompt Japan to consider ‘all options’
description: Japan's car industry employs 5.5 million people: Domestic employment will be impacted by any shift of production to the U.S. (Photo by Arisa Moriyama) Tokyo and Seoul to pursue exemptions through negotiations Nikkei staff writers March 27, 2025 15:02 JST TOKYO — Japan’s Prime Minister on Thursday sounded the alarm after U.S. President Donald Trump announced 25% tariffs on imported cars and car parts . “We need to consider appropriate responses,” Shigeru Ishiba told lawmakers during a parliamentary session. “All options will be on the table.” The move appears to have come as a surprise to Japan, where it is seen as undercutting a bilateral agreement made in September 2019 between Trump and then Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. That limited trade deal opened Japan’s market to more American farm goods. It says the two countries will “refrain from taking measures against the spirit of these agreements.” Japanese automakers responded cautiously to the announcement. Toyota, Subaru, Mazda and Honda issued brief statements, saying they were assessing the potential impact. The industry’s muted response reflects its delicate position: Companies need to side with the American public as major business operators in the U.S. while being concerned about the tariffs’ impact on their domestic operations. Tariffs of 2.5% and 25% are already levied on imported cars and trucks. When the new tariffs come into effect on April 3, they will go up to 27.5% and 50%, respectively. The 25% tariffs will also apply to automotive parts such as engines and transmissions and will take effect by May 3 at the latest. Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshimasa Hayashi said the government intended to negotiate exemptions. Economists said it was not clear how exemptions could be secured, but there are several options. Among the options Japan is likely to consider are voluntary export curbs, a pledge to increase imports for such items as natural gas, grain and meat, and replacing Russian natural gas with that from the U.S., according to economists. In 2023, 8.9% of Japan’s natural gas imports came from Russia compared with 7.2% from the U.S. “Japan is likely to be looking at all these options,” said Koichi Fujishiro, senior economist at Dai-ichi Life Research Institute. South Korea is similarly expected to seek exemptions. Analysts said its negotiating position would be helped by South Korean automaker Hyundai Motor Group’s announcement of a $21 billion U.S. investment earlier this week, which was hailed by Trump as a “clear demonstration that tariffs very strongly work.” “The U.S. imposed the 25% tariffs on all imported cars by principle,” said Esther Yim, a senior analyst at Samsung Securities. “Washington may negotiate with each country later, and I think the investment can be used as a leverage.” South Korea’s industry ministry promised an emergency response by April, to assist the country’s automakers which are expected to face “considerable difficulties” when the tariffs take effect. Over the years, global carmakers have shifted toward local production to avoid trade friction. As such, 60% of Japanese cars sold in the U.S. are made in the U.S., according to Mitsubishi Research Institute. The share drops to 40% for Korean cars. The share is as high as 70% for European brands. Despite Ishiba insisting all options are on the table, few analysts expect Japan to resort to countervailing measures, at least not at this point. “There would be very little Japan would gain from retaliating against the U.S. tariffs,” Fujishiro said. During a summit with Trump in February, Ishiba made a point of Japan being the biggest investor in the U.S. and a major job creator, and promised to work toward increasing the balance of Japanese investment to $1 trillion from $783.3 billion in 2023. Autos are Japan’s largest export item to the U.S., totaling 6 trillion yen ($40 billion) and accounting for 28% of Japan’s total exports in 2024. The amount is equivalent to 1% of Japan’s nominal gross domestic product. Nomura Research Institute’s Takahide Kiuchi estimates that 25% tariffs would reduce Japanese auto exports to the U.S. by 15% to 20%, lowering Japan’s GDP by 0.2%. If Japanese automakers try to respond to this by shifting production to the U.S., that would reduce domestic employment and hollow out the nation’s economy in the long term. “[Car] exports from Japan are essential to complement Japanese automakers’ local production, and to provide a line up of attractive cars … to meet the various needs by American customers through auto dealers in each state in the U.S.,” said Masanori Katayama, chairman of the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association, during a press conference last week. When the U.S. implements the tariff, Katayama said, “it is expected that there will be significant production adjustment. “The Japanese automobile industry is not just made up of carmakers, but also includes parts suppliers and 5.5 million people.” Katayama insisted that the industry and Japanese government should team up to take action and keep domestic supply chains intact. “We hope that the U.S. government will continue to develop policies and a business environment that provide high levels of predictability and allow Japanese automakers to invest with confidence,” he added. The tariffs are expected to hurt American automakers as well, as they too procure parts and carry out production on a global basis to keep costs down and make their cars competitive in the marketplace. General Motors could fall into an operating loss on an annual basis because of its reliance on factories in Mexico, Nomura analyst Anindya Das said. Toyota could see a 30% decline in operating profit, he added. “The tariffs imposed today will make it more expensive to produce and sell cars in the United States, ultimately leading to higher prices, fewer options for consumers, and fewer manufacturing jobs in the U.S.,” said Jennifer Safavian, president and CEO of Autos Drive America, an industry group representing international automakers with operations in the U.S. including Toyota, Honda, Nissan and others.

title: Taiwan’s new civil defense drill prepares for worst, from nature or China
description: Participants in Taiwan's civil defense drill tend to a "patient" in Tainan on March 27. (Photo by Cheng Ting-fang) Diplomats from U.S., Japan, Europe observe first test of 'whole society' resilience CHENG TING-FANG and LAULY LI March 27, 2025 14:25 JST TAINAN, Taiwan — Over 1,500 people gathered in Taiwan’s southern city of Tainan on Thursday to test the ability of civil society — as opposed to the military — to respond to disasters amid deteriorating relations with China. President Lai Ching-te hosted the drill — the first live, civilian-based exercise of its kind under his concept of “whole of society” resilience. Participants ranged from local and central government officials to volunteer firefighters and police officers, as well as about 500 regular civilians, according to a senior Taiwanese government official. The military was not directly involved, apart from providing medical aid and tents for logistical support. The absence of the armed forces was intended to provide a clearer picture of the resilience of local officials and civilians. Ambulance sirens blared as the “injured” were brought to temporary medical centers for treatment, part of preparations for a cyberattack that disrupts hospitals. The scenario simulated a series of complex disasters: a massive explosion at the Port of Anping, followed by a powerful 8.0-magnitude earthquake originating in the Manila Trench, and a devastating tsunami expected to strike southern Taiwan. But the elephant in the room was China, which has stepped up military pressure on the island with its own large-scale drills and incursions, raising fears that it could one day attempt to assert the Communist Party’s territorial claim to the island democracy by force. Both President Lai and Vice President Hsiao Bi-khim attended Thursday’s exercise. “I saw a wife really crying as she reported to the police, I saw a person pretend he broke his bone, and I saw doctors seriously treating the patients,” Lai said. Praising participants’ cooperation, he continued, “I saw massive strength coming from civilians.” It was also a demonstration to the world, as foreign diplomats including Raymond Greene, director of the American Institute in Taiwan — Washington’s de-facto embassy — donned vests as they watched the proceedings. The international observers included representatives from 13 democracies, also including Japan and European countries. Observers from Finland, Israel and other countries known for civil resilience were among them. Taiwan’s President Lai Ching-te, center, attends the Tainan exercise. Raymond Greene, the de facto U.S. envoy, looks on behind him. (Photo by Cheng Ting-fang) The civil defense drill came a week after the Lai administration held an “immediate combat readiness” exercise, simulating a scenario in which China unexpectedly pivots from a military exercise into a real attack. Recently released plans for this summer’s annual Han Kuang military exercise also mentioned, for the first time, 2027 as a potential year for a Chinese invasion. Tensions rose further this month after Lai publicly referred to China as a “foreign hostile force” for the first time and warned about increasing threats of Chinese infiltration. This was met with an angry response from Beijing and fresh military drills near Taiwan. Ian Chen Tsung-yen, director of the Institute of Political Science at National Sun Yat-sen University, said the civil exercise is crucial for the island’s defensive capabilities in light of escalating tensions across the Taiwan Strait. “China’s harassment via air and sea is getting worse,” Chen told Nikkei Asia. “It is very important to increase the Taiwanese public’s awareness over Beijing’s aggression.” The professor added that “if a military conflict breaks out, followed by disasters, our military won’t have the capacity to conduct rescue missions. It will rely on our civil defense capability.” A middle school doubles as an emergency center. (Photo by Cheng Ting-fang) Soon after he took office in May 2024, Lai set up a Whole-of-Society Defense Resilience Committee, bringing together top officials, civil society groups, experts and business representatives. The committee aims to bolster civilians’ preparedness and training for all types of incidents, from natural disasters to military attacks, and to strengthen the resilience of strategic supplies, critical infrastructure, medical care and other vital areas. Unlike previous drills that were based on scripted settings and planned responses, the exercise on Thursday had no staged plans. Instead, participants were tasked with acting out scenarios and responding on the fly. “We can’t afford to not prepare, due to current geopolitics,” Lai said. “If we prepare well, we can protect our safety. … We need to demonstrate that we are prepared and ready so that we can have peace and stability.”

title: China demand slump hits earnings at top consumer goods companies
description: Consumers in China are reining in spending, dragging down earnings at some consumer goods companies. © Reuters Food, household goods makers looking for overseas growth face price-dumping claims WATARU SUZUKI and KENJI KAWASE March 26, 2025 20:19 JST Updated on March 27, 2025 13:55 JST HONG KONG — China’s top food and household product companies said they would step up efforts to seek growth overseas after weak demand at home dented earnings last year. China Mengniu Dairy, a leader in the country’s dairy product industry, reported a 10% decline in revenue to 88.67 billion yuan ($12.21 billion) for 2024, with a 98% drop in net profit to 104.50 million yuan. On Thursday, the day after the numbers came out, CEO Gao Fei told reporters that the double-digit shrinkage of the top line was mainly due to “industrywide” price declines, amid what management described as “lower-than-expected consumer demand.” The company’s chief financial officer, Zhang Ping, stressed that the problem “was not about quantity but about price.” Mengniu’s main liquid milk business was hit especially hard, as revenue from this segment, which makes up over 80% of total sales, fell by 11% on the year. Cost cuts partially softened the blows, but profit was nearly wiped out by impairment losses on goodwill and intangible assets, including Bellamy’s, an Australian subsidiary acquired in 2019. Still, despite the risks of managing international businesses, Gao vowed to “accelerate the expansion abroad,” mainly eyeing Southeast Asia, as the company’s Aice ice cream as become a leading brand in Indonesia and the Philippines. Mengniu CEO Gao Fei, center, drinks his own product at a briefing in Hong Kong on March 27. He blamed price declines as the main cause of a double-digit fall in last year’s revenue. (Photo by Kenji Kawase) Hengan International Group, a major producer of tissues and disposable diapers, reported on Tuesday that net profit fell 18% from a year ago to 2.3 billion yuan in 2024. “We’ll be looking for more opportunities overseas,” Hengan International Group CEO Hui Ching Lau told reporters on Tuesday. Lau said the company will be “promoting the development of overseas business as an important strategy this year more than before,” although he did not specify targets. Lau noted that “competition is extremely fierce” in China and the company is suffering the impact of a price war between e-commerce operators such as Pinduoduo and Douyin. For example, Hengan’s 24-box tissue pack is sold for just 33 yuan on Pinduoduo compared to 62 yuan on Taobao, which is owned by Alibaba Group. Higher raw material prices and increased spending on promotions also eroded Hengan’s profit margin. “If everyone were to operate at a loss continuously, a company wouldn’t be able to keep going,” said Lau, projecting that such a trend would persist until the market undergoes consolidation. He added that China’s tissue market remains extremely fragmented, pointing to the “several hundred” small factories operating in just the one city of Baoding, in northeastern Hebei province. Meanwhile, bottled water maker Nongfu Spring’s annual revenue and net profit grew less than 1%, dragged down by a slump in the second half of the year. In particular, its packaged water business took a sharp hit, falling 21% from a year ago to 15.95 billion yuan. The company blamed the decline on “a surge of online attacks and malicious defamation” since February last year after Chinese nationalists hurled accusations at its red-capped water bottles for resembling the Japanese flag when held up against a piece of white paper. The company later introduced a new bottle with a green cap. Hengan International Group CEO Hui Ching Lau, middle, expects China’s tissue and disposable diaper market to consolidate in the near future due to “fierce competition.” (Photo by Wataru Suzuki) Separately, founder Zhong Shanshan also criticized the cutthroat price competition among online marketplace players, reportedly describing the pressure piled on sellers as “bad money driving out the good.” In an earnings report released on Tuesday, Zhong said the company will “actively seek market development opportunities overseas.” Nongfu generates nearly all of its revenue from mainland China. Results at both Hengan and Nongfu missed analyst estimates published on FactSet. China faces deflationary pressures on the back of a property market downturn and as consumers reined in spending due to weak job prospects. The consumer price index for the first two months of 2025 slipped 0.1% annually, bogged down by declines in food and consumer goods prices. Given weak demand at home, some companies are expanding abroad but such moves have led to accusations by other countries, including the U.S., that China was dumping excess capacity overseas. Premier Li Qiang has acknowledged the issue, saying in a government work report released earlier this month that China will “take comprehensive steps to address rat race competition.” WH Group Chairman Wan Long, right, told reporters in Hong Kong on Tuesday that the U.S.-China tariff war will “not have a significant impact” on the meat processing company. (Photo by Wataru Suzuki) Other companies that have a presence overseas fared better. The world’s largest pork producer WH Group, said stronger earnings in Europe and the U.S. helped offset lower packaged meat and pork sales in China. WH Group reported an 8% decline in packaged meat sales in China, which it attributed to a “lack of effective demand from the market.” Sales in Europe, however, grew by 25%, thanks to its acquisition of Spanish meat producer Argal which was completed in March 2024. In January, WH Group listed its U.S. meat processing subsidiary Smithfield on the Nasdaq exchange. Chairman and CEO Wan Long said the company would “continue to accelerate expansion in the U.S. and Europe” through acquisitions and would not be as active in China. When asked about the impact of the intensifying trade war between the U.S. and China, Wan said the additional tariffs would “not have a significant impact” on its business due to resilient demand in the U.S. and the group’s global footprint. WH Group said it would adjust its product mix to minimize the impact. On a positive note, higher spending for collectible toys propelled Pop Mart’s net profit by 189% annually to 3.1 billion yuan. Known for its animated characters made of vinyl, the group’s revenue in mainland China grew 52%, while overseas sales jumped nearly fivefold. Pop Mart CEO Wang Ning said during an analyst meeting on Wednesday that the company aims to increase its total revenue by 50% in 2025. Part of the strategy is to raise the ratio of its overseas revenue from 39% in 2024 to over 50%. He added that domestic performance in the first quarter has “exceeded our expectations,” thanks to hugely popular figurines from blockbuster movie “Nezha 2.” The company’s Hong Kong-listed shares climbed over 11% after his remarks.

title: North Korea has sent 3,000 more troops to Russia, South assesses
description: North Korea is also supporting Russia's war in Ukraine by shipping weapons. © KCNA via Kyodo Amid concerns of Russian tech transfers, Kim Jong Un observes attack drone tests March 27, 2025 13:32 JST SEOUL (AP) — North Korea sent around 3,000 additional troops to Russia in January and February in continued support for Russian President Vladimir Putin’s war on Ukraine, South Korea’s military said Thursday in its latest assessment. The South’s Joint Chiefs of Staff said North Korea has also been sending more missiles, artillery equipment and ammunition to help Russia and that North Korea could increase its weapons supplies further depending on the war situation. Russia and Ukraine recently agreed on a limited ceasefire, though both sides have accused each other of violations. The military equipment North Korea has sent to Russia includes a “considerable amount” of short-range ballistic missiles, 170-millimeter self-propelled howitzers and around 220 units of 240-millimeter multiple rocket launchers. North Korea has sent approximately 11,000 military personnel to fight in the war against Ukraine in its first involvement in a large-scale conflict since the 1950-53 Korean War, and the Joint Chiefs assessed that around 4,000 of them have been killed or injured. South Korea’s National Intelligence Service previously attributed the high North Korean casualties to the troops’ likely struggles in adapting to drones and other elements of modern warfare. North Korean troops are further disadvantaged by the crude tactics of their Russian commanders, who have sent them into assault campaigns without providing rear-fire support, the spy agency told lawmakers in January. Still, Ukrainian military and intelligence officials have assessed that the North Koreans are gaining crucial battlefield experience and have been key to Russia’s strategy of overwhelming Ukraine by throwing large numbers of soldiers into the battle for Kursk. The South Korean military report came after North Korean leader Kim Jong Un last week in Pyongyang expressed his unwavering support for Russia’s war in Ukraine during a meeting with Sergei Shoigu, a top Russian security official. State media reports said Kim and Shoigu reaffirmed their commitment to uphold a major mutual defense treaty agreed upon last year. Kim’s military support of Russia has raised concerns that he may receive Russian technology transfers in return, further strengthening the threat posed by his nuclear-armed military. Experts say drones are among the potential areas where North Korea might seek to acquire Russian technology and know-how. North Korean state media said Thursday that Kim observed tests of newly developed reconnaissance and attack drones this week and called for their increased production. Kim in recent months has been emphasizing the development of drones, and the tests were the latest display of his country’s growing military capabilities. Photos released by North Korea’s official Korean Central News Agency show Kim observing what appears to be a large reconnaissance drone roughly resembling Boeing’s E-7 Wedgetail airborne warning and control aircraft. Other images show exploding drones crashing into military vehicles used as targets. The agency said the test demonstrated the reconnaissance drone’s ability to track multiple targets and monitor troop movements on land and at sea, potentially enhancing North Korea’s intelligence-gathering operations and ability to neutralize enemy threats. The report said the new exploding drones are designed for various attack missions and feature unspecified artificial intelligence capabilities. Kim expressed satisfaction with the drones’ performance and approved plans to expand production, emphasizing that drones and AI should be “top” priorities in efforts to advance his armed forces and adapt them to modern warfare, KCNA said. The agency said the tests took place as Kim visited a drone technology complex and an electronic warfare research group on Tuesday and Wednesday. Kim in August and November also inspected demonstrations of drones that explode on impact. When asked about the new reconnaissance drone, which North Korean state media unveiled for the first time, Lee Sung Joon, spokesperson for South Korea’s Joint Chiefs of Staff, said the North likely modified an existing aircraft to create an early-warning drone and may have used certain components from Russia. He said North Korea was possibly exaggerating the drone’s capabilities. “As you can see, it looks quite cumbersome, and we assess that it’s likely vulnerable to interception,” Lee said during a briefing, without elaborating further on the assessment.

title: Trump tariffs hit Japanese, South Korean carmakers; Toyota, Hyundai slide
description: Following Trump's Wednesday announcement on auto tariffs, Japan automakers underperformed the benchmark Nikkei Stock Average and the broader Tokyo Stock Price Index on Thursday, which were both down around 1%. (Nikkei montage/Source photo by Kaisuke Ohta) The day's drop is just the beginning, if Trump keeps policy: Jefferies LISA KIM LISA KIM and JAEWON KIM March 27, 2025 12:50 JST TOKYO/SEOUL — Shares of Japanese and South Korean automakers slid Thursday morning after U.S. President Donald Trump imposed 25% tariffs on all cars shipped to that country in his latest trade salvo. Smaller Japanese automakers dependent on the U.S. for sales but behind in onshore production were hit hard. Subaru dropped 6.3%, and Mazda Motor lost 5.8%. Toyota, the country’s largest automobile manufacturer, was off 3.3%, and Honda was down around 2%. Automakers underperformed the benchmark Nikkei Stock Average and the broader Tokyo Stock Price Index, which were both down around 1%. The yen weakened to the mid-150 level after the dollar strengthened on the tariff announcement. “Markets will observe the sustainability of these tariffs, or whether Trump, often referred to as a deal maker, will roll back them when offered incentives,” said Shrikant Kale, senior quantitative strategist at Jefferies in Hong Kong. “In the absence of that, This is just the beginning of a multi-month story.” Subaru, Mazda Motor and Mitsubishi Motors are among Japanese manufacturers with a market capitalization of more than $2 billion that have a greater U.S. sales exposure than U.S. production, according to a report Kale published in February. Subaru, for instance, generates around 73% of its sales in the U.S. and manufactures 29% of its products there, according to the report. While more time is needed to see how the auto tariffs play out, Kale said his analysis from earlier in the year that assumed 10% levies and a 30% absorption rate showed auto earnings would drop by 3.4%. The auto tariffs will take effect on April 3 , a day after Trump is expected to impose reciprocal tariffs , much of which is still unknown. Goldman Sachs, whose baseline scenario called a 25 percentage point increase in tariffs on all car imports, said the levies would have a “significant” impact on Japanese autos and auto parts makers. Autos account for more than 30% of Japan’s exports to the U.S. and 7% of total exports, according to a report economists led by Tomohiro Ota wrote Wednesday. The 25% tariffs on autos would also drag Japan’s gross domestic product by more than 0.1 percentage points, the report said. In the near term, “the decline in auto exports could be larger,” the report said, “due to factors such as consumers postponing purchases in anticipation of an early end to the tariff increase and a pullback from front-loaded demand ahead of the tariff.” Elsewhere in Asia, South Korea’s largest carmaker Hyundai Motor and its sister firm Kia Motors slid 4% and 3%, respectively, on Thursday morning. The firms together ship around 1 million autos from South Korea to the U.S. U.S. auto tariffs are a setback for Hyundai Motor Group, whose executive chairman Chung Eui-sun stood beside Trump just two days ago as the president referred to the firm’s $21 billion investment in the U.S. as “a clear demonstration that tariffs very strongly work.” The South Korean automaker on Thursday held an opening ceremony for its new plant in Georgia. The vehicle assembly and battery plant has the capacity to initially produce 300,000 electric and hybrid vehicles per year for its Hyundai Motor, Kia Motors and Hyundai’s luxury brand Genesis, the company said. “With the rich history of craftsmanship and manufacturing in this community, together with the talented workforce at Hyundai Motor Group Metaplant America, we are building the future of mobility with America, in America,” Chung said at the ceremony.

title: India seeks to offset Trump tariffs by negotiating bilateral pacts
description: A mobile crane carries a container to stack it at Thar Dry Port in Sanand in the western state of Gujarat, India. © Reuters Delhi speeds up talks with U.S., while reaching out to EU, U.K. and New Zealand KIRAN SHARMA KIRAN SHARMA March 27, 2025 12:40 JST NEW DELHI — India has stepped up efforts to strike trade deals with other countries in an apparent bid to minimize the impact of U.S. President Donald Trump’s looming tariffs, even as New Delhi and Washington are finalizing the framework for a “mutually beneficial” bilateral trade pact. Ahead of Trump’s April 2 deadline to impose reciprocal tariffs on countries, Brendan Lynch, assistant U.S. Trade Representative for South and Central Asia, and other American officials are in India on a five-day visit through Saturday for meetings with Indian counterparts as part of ongoing trade talks. “This visit reflects the United States’ continued commitment to advancing a productive and balanced trade relationship with India,” a U.S. embassy statement said earlier this week. While the specific agenda of the talks has not been shared, officials in New Delhi said that the shape and scope of the proposed bilateral trade agreement (BTA) would be confirmed by both sides. “Contours of the BTA will be finalized,” one of them said on condition of anonymity. Randhir Jaiswal, India’s External Affairs Ministry spokesperson, said on Friday that the two sides “are actively working to build a framework for the BTA, which would aim to expand trade, enhance market access, reduce tariff and non-tariff barriers, and deepen supply chain integration.” The two sides have announced that they plan to negotiate the “first tranche,” or phase one, of the BTA by the fall. While officials have not disclosed what the first phase would entail, local media reported that it is expected to cover issues concerning goods trading, while the second tranche, which is likely to be the final one, may involve topics like technology transfer. Prime Minister Narendra Modi in February visited Washington where he and Trump resolved to deepen ties and expand trade to $500 billion by 2030, from around $200 billion now. U.S. President Donald Trump and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi shake hands as they attend a joint press conference at the White House in Washington on Feb. 13.   © Reuters According to India’s Commerce Secretary Sunil Barthwal, the two sides are negotiating a “multi-sectoral” agreement. Brokerage Nomura sees the ongoing BTA negotiations as an encouraging sign for India. “It signals that, while India is in the direct line of fire on U.S. reciprocal tariffs, the BTA could reduce the impact of any such tariffs on India,” it said in a recent note. By the Modi-Trump meeting, it added, India had already cut duties in sectors like textiles, motorcycles and bourbon whiskey. “India has also avoided any tit-for-tat response to provocations from Mr. Trump,” the brokerage said. While India lowered import duties on certain items as concessions to the Trump administration, New Delhi more broadly “appears to have redoubled efforts to strike trade deals” with other countries, “most likely in an effort to strengthen its export base beyond the U.S.,” Capital Economics said in a note on March 20. India and the European Union announced late February they were aiming to conclude a trade agreement by the end of this year. Days before, New Delhi resumed trade talks with London after they were paused in May last year. India and New Zealand in mid-March also announced the resumption of trade talks that fell apart in 2015. However, India must exercise caution while negotiating the BTA with the U.S., said Ajay Srivastava, founder of New Delhi-based Global Trade Research Initiative think tank. The deal faces “congressional scrutiny, possible amendments, delays, or outright rejection,” without the application of a special power known as the Trade Promotion Authority (TPA), Srivastava said. This power must be given by Congress to the president and will help speed up and simplify trade negotiations with other countries. However, the TPA has not been renewed since it lapsed in 2021. In addition, after signing a trade agreement, the U.S. often uses its own certification or review process to judge if the partner country has been implementing all aspects of the deal, “sometimes using this to pressure for more changes or new terms,” said Srivastava. The one-sided certification and absence of TPA will “give the U.S. room to change the deal later or ask for more than what was originally agreed,” he added. World Trade Organization data from 2023 showed that India’s simple average tariff rate was 17%, compared with 3.3% for the U.S. Trump has repeatedly singled out India for its high tariff rates even though he enjoys warm personal rapport with Modi. The U.S. trade deficit with India in goods was $45.7 billion in 2024, a 5.4% increase over the previous year, an issue that the Trump administration would be looking to address in trade negotiations with New Delhi.

title: How Alaskan energy can power the U.S.-Japan relationship
description: A U.S.-Japan partnership to deliver affordable energy to Japan and our other friends in the Pacific should be a no-brainer. © Reuters Partnership can secure reliable, stable and affordable energy for generations to come March 27, 2025 12:05 JST Mike Dunleavy, a Republican, is governor of Alaska. At the U.S.-Japan summit on Feb. 7, President Donald Trump noted that “Japan will soon begin importing historic new shipments of clean American liquefied natural gas in record numbers,” hinting at “a joint venture of some type between Japan and us having to do with Alaskan oil and gas.” This is a proposal both the U.S. and Japan should rally behind. Japan is one of America’s closest and most important allies, and Alaska is a major reason why. Natural gas from Alaska’s Cook Inlet played a crucial role in Japan’s postwar recovery and economic rise. Indeed, Tokyo’s partnership with the city of Juneau helped transform Japan into a manufacturing and technological powerhouse. Meanwhile, Japan’s dynamism, innovation and industrial output have enriched the American people and cemented Tokyo as a critical Western ally. At the White House summit, President Trump and Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba did not solidify a deal to expand Japanese access to Alaskan energy. But with a U.S. administration that prioritizes energy production and security as well as economic growth — with threats to freedom and prosperity multiplying around the globe — the time is right to take the historically vital Alaska-Japan relationship to a new level. The case in point is the Alaska Gasline, an 800-mile pipeline that will deliver LNG from Alaska’s energy-rich North Slope to global markets, including Japan. The North Slope holds 35 trillion cubic feet of proven natural gas, with another 200 trillion in potential deposits. Pipeline access to these deposits would offer Japan a reliable, affordable and strategically sensible power source while strengthening American energy security and the U.S.-Japan relationship. America learned early in its history that economic ties have a huge impact on a nation’s strategic prospects. Henry Clay saw U.S. dependence on goods from the British Empire as a hindrance to our independence — and he was right. As Europe’s struggle to wean itself off Russian energy demonstrates, maintaining reliable and stable energy partnerships is more important than ever. Alaska Gov. Mike Dunleavy speaks in Houston, Texas, on March 14, 2025.    © Reuters Currently, Japan — the world’s second largest net energy importer — relies largely on Saudi Arabia, Qatar, and the United Arab Emirates for oil. While these are credible energy partners, they neither share Japan’s moral and strategic interests nor its commitment to security and prosperity in the Pacific. Alaska, on the other hand, shares these core values. A U.S.-Japan partnership to deliver affordable energy to Japan and our other friends in the Pacific should be a no-brainer. It would ensure that the free world is fueling the free world. Alaska sits at the crossroads between Asia and North America, and U.S. companies lead the world in clean and efficient energy extraction. We are uniquely positioned to supply Japan and other Indo-Pacific partners with natural gas and clean hydrogen for decades to come. Japan, for its part, can use its unique expertise in the LNG sector to help distribute American energy to the rest of the Indo-Pacific. Japanese companies are the largest LNG plant builders, the largest gas turbine providers, and have the largest LNG shipping capacity in the region. Japan’s world-class carbon-capture technology will also be critical to assuring the carbon neutrality of this project. As America seeks to rebuild manufacturing capacity to compete with China, we will need to invest in strong, reliable allies like Japan. A new LNG pipeline project would help Tokyo secure this mutually beneficial investment. For maximum benefit, the Trump and Ishiba administrations should build on their productive engagement and ensure this project gets started soon. Japan and America align on the values of representative government, trade, security, and a world order that supports prosperity and freedom. We have worked together for decades to build a better future. Let us build on this tradition by securing reliable, stable and affordable energy for the next generations.

title: Australian AI startup creates ‘perfect victims’ to bait scammers
description: As scammers use AI to ensnare victims, companies like Aparate.ai are using the technology to counter scams. Apate.ai bots keep swindlers tied up while eliciting information SHAUN TURTON March 27, 2025 10:13 JST SYDNEY — A man calling himself Dayton phones saying he’s from Amazon. He informs the person on the line there has been suspicious activity on his account: someone paid $999.98 for a MacBook Pro to be delivered to San Diego, California. “You for real, mate?” comes the response. “I’m in Sydney, not bloody California. I mean, no, I definitely didn’t buy anything like that. Are you serious?” “Dayton” is not from Amazon, but a scammer in a global illicit industry estimated to have stolen more than $1 trillion from people around the world, according to one study. In this attempt, however, Dayton is the one being tricked. His Australian-accented intended victim — whom he chats with for seven minutes — is not a real person, but one of the AI bots created by Australian company Apate.ai. As scammers turn to AI to supercharge their swindles, the tech startup is wielding AI in the global fightback against the illicit industry, creating “victims” to soak up scammers’ time and gather insights into their activities. Their Apate Voice product creates AI personas that field calls, engaging with scammers whose tactics range from impersonating bank staff and merchants to pushing fraudulent investment schemes. The company also created Apate Text, which does the same thing for text exchanges. For the voice bots, the company’s fake victims vary in age, accent and the languages they use. Their dispositions can shift from wary and confused to agreeable and amazed to bored and distracted. Their goal is to keep the scammer tied up while gathering information on the type of scam and any details, like bank accounts. In another call, a scammer impersonates a representative from Australia’s National Broadband Network and at one point asks, “Do you know where your router is?” The bot appears to fumble about. “Sorry, hang on a minute, yeah, umm, it’s near, umm, the TV,” it says, conceding it’s not great with technology. Apate.ai currently has 10 employees, four members of the founding team and six developers. Its founder, Dali Kaafar, is a professor at Macquarie University, where he’s executive of the institution’s cybersecurity hub. The idea’s genesis came when Kaafar was interrupted by a scam call during a family picnic. The company’s chief commercial officer, Brad Joffe, said Apate.ai is “creating the perfect victim.” The power of AI learning means their bots continually get better at leading on scammers, whose frustration is a keenly monitored metric. “We might be one of the only startups in the world that celebrates when people swear using our product,” he said. The global scam industry has boomed in recent years. A 2024 Global Anti-Scam Alliance report estimated people around the world lost $1.03 trillion in 2023, with only 4% of victims able to fully recover their money. Southeast Asian countries like Cambodia and Myanmar have emerged as hotspots for scam operations, which are also linked to human trafficking. Meanwhile, banks, utilities and financial payment providers are responding to pressure to improve protections for customers. In the U.K., telecom company O2 found that 1 in 5 people report a scam call every week, with the company also turning to an AI bot solution. Unveiled last year, the AI “granny” named “dAIsy” wastes scammers time with rambling answers, including references to its cat “Fluffy.” In this environment, Apate.ai sees many opportunities for its product, which can handle tens of thousands of calls and is already being used in Australia, the U.K. and Singapore with collaborations with governments, cryptocurrency exchanges and financial institutions. Between December 2020 and September last year, Australian telecommunication providers blocked more than 2.2 billion scam calls and 788 million scam text messages. Apate.ai is collaborating with Australia’s Commonwealth Bank and is currently in trial with one telco in the same country, which diverts its blocked scam calls to the company’s bots. Joffe said the system could detect within the first five to 10 seconds whether a call was legitimate or not. Those wrongly screened are forwarded back to the telco. From the scam calls, the company generates data that is fed back to a dashboard as part of its Apate Insights product, showing things like types of scams and what companies are being impersonated — information which can then be used to generate real-time warnings. It can also flag any personally identifiable information disclosed by the scammer — like bank account details or websites — and create alerts. Joffe warned scams were getting increasingly sophisticated, noting AI-powered technology could now clone voices with only 10 seconds of material, leading to swindles like the “Hey Mum” scam, where the fraudsters pretend to be children in trouble that need money quickly. In such an AI-driven cat-and-mouse game, it made sense to develop a strong defense. “If they’re using it as a sword, we need it as a shield,” he said.

title: Indonesia’s depreciating rupiah: 5 things to know
description: Indonesian bank notes. The rupiah has weakened by about 3% this year against the U.S. dollar, making it among the poorest performing emerging market currencies. Investors are skeptical about President Prabowo Subianto's economic agenda © Reuters Exporters benefit while importers and consumers contend with higher prices ISMI DAMAYANTI and NANA SHIBATA March 27, 2025 09:24 JST JAKARTA — The Indonesian rupiah fell on Tuesday to its lowest level against the U.S dollar since the 1998 Asian Financial Crisis, exceeding its depreciation during the COVID-19 pandemic. It has weakened 3% this year, making it one of the poorest performing emerging market currencies. Indonesia’s economy is deeply reliant on exchange rate stability, from corporate transactions to the importing of industrial supplies, and Bank Indonesia, the central bank, has intervened to prevent further weakening. While exporters of key commodities like palm oil are reaping windfall gains from the weakening rupiah, the other side of the coin is more troubling. Importers and consumers will have to contend with rising costs that threaten to erode purchasing power and strain the broader economy. Here are five things to know about the rupiah’s depreciation and what it could mean for Southeast Asia’s biggest economy. Who gains from a weakened rupiah? Traders and exporters of commodities such as coal, palm oil, fisheries and other raw materials who earn revenue in foreign currencies are benefiting from the rupiah’s depreciation. Coal miners are particularly enjoying a windfall, as most of their production costs are denominated in rupiah. “We will remain cautious as expanding into new global markets for coal remains a challenge,” said Gita Mahyarani, acting executive director of the Indonesian Coal Mining Association (ACMI). Local coal miner Indo Tambangraya Megah is seeing a positive impact from the weakened rupiah, as the majority of its revenue is denominated in U.S. dollars. “We do have some expenses in U.S. dollars, but they make up a much smaller portion compared to our overall earnings,” said Yulius Kurniawan Gozali, the company’s Director of Risk, Strategy, and Communication. Palm oil producers are also seeing gains from the stronger U.S. dollar, although they cautioned that the benefits may be short lived. “If the U.S. dollar remains strong in the long term, we’ll eventually feel the pressure on the cost side, especially for imported fertilizers,” said Eddy Martono, chairman of the Indonesian Palm Oil Association. Benny Soetrisno, chairman of the Indonesian Exporters Association, said the depreciating rupiah was a blessing for exporting companies. “For those whose production costs are in rupiah, they will get additional benefit,” he said. Who suffers from the rupiah’s depreciation? Importers and businesses that depend on imported goods and raw materials are feeling the pressure from the weakening currency. This particularly includes those in the manufacturing and pharmaceutical sectors. According to Soetrisno of the exporters association, even manufacturers with export products remain vulnerable: “Around 45% of players in Indonesia’s manufacturing sector still rely on imported raw materials.” Indonesian pharmaceutical giant Kalbe Farma said it is facing mounting pressure from rising import costs and the limited availability of locally sourced raw materials. “About 60% to 70% of our imports are transacted in U.S. dollars,” said Hari Nugroho, the company’s head of external and stakeholder relations. To mitigate currency risks, Kalbe Farma has benefited from a previous joint venture with a Chinese partner, which allows for payments in yuan for materials sourced from China. “In addition, the company has also set aside U.S. dollar reserves to cushion against further exchange rate volatility,” he said. Companies with U.S. dollar liabilities are also facing rising loan repayment costs, which could squeeze profitability. Among the most high-profile businesses are a state-owned construction company, Hutama Karya, which holds $600 million in global bonds that mature in 2030. What is the likely consumer fallout? Consumers are already starting to feel the pinch, with rising prices of goods affecting household spending and economic sentiment. “Imported goods and services are becoming more expensive, potentially driving up inflation and reducing purchasing power,” said Hosianna Situmorang, a Bank Danamon economist. For Firna Ramdani, a Jakarta-based officer worker who cares for a diabetic sibling, the rupiah’s decline is a growing concern: “We might soon be told by the pharmacist that the price of my brother’s medication is going up because the medicine is imported.” Last month, the Central Statistics Agency (BPS) reported that prices fell 0.09% year on year, the first annual deflation since 2000. But inflation is expected to return this month due to the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan. Meanwhile the economic downturn has already resulted in tens of thousands of layoffs in several manufacturing sectors. How have the authorities reacted? Coordinating Economic Minister Airlangga Hartarto remains confident that the rupiah’s depreciation is temporary, citing strong domestic fundamentals. “Our economy is fundamentally strong, the market has rebounded and there are positive sentiments from the Bank Rakyat Indonesia and Bank Mandiri shareholders meetings,” he said on Wednesday, referring to two of the largest publicly-listed, state-owned lenders. Hartarto noted that external factors continue to pose challenges to stabilizing the rupiah. “Bank Indonesia will take measures to maintain [rupiah] stability,” he said. Bank Indonesia’s head of macroprudential policy, Solikin Juhro, said on Wednesday that the current situation is very different from the 1997-1998 financial crisis. “We’ve learned a lot since then. Back in 1998, we couldn’t detect the vulnerabilities in time,” he told a press briefing. He said that recent robust performances at most corporations mean financial capacity remains strong: “This helps keep household risks in check and incomes remain within a relatively safe zone.” How and when might the situation turn around? Situmorang of Bank Danamon said that in the short term, BI’s intervention could help stabilize the currency. “But the large amount of DNDF maturities will keep rupiah under pressure,” she said, referring to BI’s intervention measures in the derivative foreign exchange market. Situmorang said a potential rebound could occur in early April after the upcoming end-of-Ramadan holiday, once capital inflows resume, “particularly if global uncertainty eases and investor sentiment improves.” But she projected that the rupiah will continue to remain weaker than 16,300 if the U.S. dollar remains strong and external risks persist. Additional reporting by Rezha Hadyan.

title: Books: Huawei’s origin story probed, but no smoking gun
description: The most revealing insight of "House of Huawei" is how the company has merged the organizing principles of its Silicon Valley peers and the Chinese Communist Party and used both to achieve global success.  © Getty Images Portrait of Chinese telecoms group distinguishes it from the Chinese state Ross O'Brien ROSS O'BRIEN March 27, 2025 08:00 JST Earlier this month, reports emerged that the Chinese telecommunications company Huawei Technologies had bought 2 million semiconductors from Taiwan’s Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. through shell companies, circumventing U.S. restrictions aimed at blocking Chinese access to advanced chips. That Huawei needs to jump through hoops to buy its chips speaks as much to the globally interconnected nature of telecoms equipment manufacturing as to the fact that it is struggling after nearly a decade-long technology cold war, in which the U.S. sees Huawei as its primary adversary. In many ways, though, it does not seem that the company, or China’s technology markets, are struggling at all: Huawei shocked the world recently with the release of the Ascend 910C, an advanced AI accelerator chip that the company plans to mass-produce this year. Huawei was established in Shenzhen, southern China, in 1987 as a contract manufacturer of telephone switches, and swiftly built a vast and integrated portfolio of telecoms network solutions, including latest-generation 5G mobile networks, in which it is the world’s largest holder of patents. By 2012 Huawei had become the world’s largest telecoms gear maker, overtaking Sweden’s Ericsson, its chief rival, and reporting 869 revenues of 869 billion yuan ($110.2 billion) in 2024. The company owes much of its success to the same ingredients found in many other high-performing high-technology startups: a business strategy focused on building world-class foundational technologies, and the leadership of a relentlessly hardworking (if somewhat obsessive) entrepreneur. But Huawei was also different from Western tech companies: a new and uniquely Chinese company, driven by a nation-building sense of urgency and patriotic self-sacrifice. Huawei has successfully merged the organizing principles of its Silicon Valley peers and the Chinese Communist Party and used both to achieve global success. This is the most revealing insight of “House of Huawei: The Secret History of China’s Most Powerful Company,” by Washington Post technology reporter Eva Dou. Written by Washington Post technology reporter Eva Dou, right, “House of Huawei” is a rare and vital account of one of the world’s most influential global technology companies. (Source photos courtesy of Penguin Random House, Denis Largeron) Dou presents a comprehensive, deeply researched and insightful look into China’s largest and most infamous tech giant. In presenting the case for what Huawei has become, Dou does not stray beyond the facts, and rarely speculates about whether the company is (as the U.S. government and others claim) the pointy tip of the CCP’s cyberespionage spear. This sober examination is probably why the book has not received more attention. “House of Huawei” provides a brisk history of China’s telecoms manufacturing industry, from its early days in a market dominated by foreign joint ventures to its leading place in the current international array of domestic national champions. Dou links Huawei’s rise to the drive and earlier experiences of its founder, Ren Zhengfei, who began his career at an army base in Guizhou, on the Chinese border with Vietnam, during the Vietnam War. Ren’s army service has, as Dou notes, long served as his “original sin” in the eyes of Huawei’s detractors, but she points out that he spent his first two years as a cook and has claimed never to have worked in a signal intelligence capacity. Dou writes that Ren’s army days “helped shape his worldview,” but she does not believe that this period was the central ingredient in Huawei’s formation, nor its enduring success. Other places and moments in China’s economic transformation were more important: Ren’s fortuitous move to the entrepreneurial hotbed of Shenzhen, and his successful talent hunting in such centers of engineering excellence as the cities of Wuhan and Chongqing. “House of Huawei” portrays Ren and his colleagues as strivers, driven by a militaristic sense of purpose, tirelessly promoting and marketing the company to a fast-growing global list of clients. At the same time, the book provides several examples of the company’s attempts to control its public image, though these do not add up to a “secret history,” as the book’s subtitle suggests. These include sly revisions of its creation myth to minimize and in some cases obscure the participation of initial shareholders other than Ren. This comes off as slightly dodgy, but not overly so when compared to the early shareholder shenanigans of U.S. tech giants such as Facebook (now Meta). Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei, right, is pictured with Chinese President Xi Jinping in 2015. In “House of Huawei,” the company’s links to the Chinese Communist Party are well documented and placed in their proper context.   © Getty Images Huawei is portrayed as a stalwart partner of the People’s Republic of China — an enterprise devoted to helping to modernize the country and burnish its fast-growing reputation as a global powerhouse. Ren’s company — and it is always Ren’s company, though he now owns only about 1% of the company’s shares — is shown to be politically bulletproof, but not a proxy actor of the Chinese state. This conclusion may have dampened the book’s reception. Many reviewers have expressed disappointment that Dou does not definitively tell us how much influence the Ministry of State Security wields over Huawei, or whether its overseas sales of switches and base stations have enabled signals intelligence for China’s international espionage efforts (as the U.S. has long claimed). That she does not speculate is a credit to Dou’s journalistic instincts, although it seems she felt compelled to do so in recounting the career of Sun Yafang, a former chairwoman with links to the MSS, of whom Dou tantalizingly writes that “perhaps that has something to do with her rapid rise through Huawei’s ranks, or perhaps not.” Huawei’s links to the CCP are well documented and placed in their proper context. A CCP party branch has been part of the company’s makeup since 1996, as was expected of any Chinese enterprise at the time, particularly one full of such commercial and technological promise. Dou looks closely at the career of Huawei’s first party branch secretary, Chen Zhufang, a retired engineer who is portrayed as a “stern grandmother” rather than an ideologue, who reinforced Huawei’s corporate culture rooted in hard, humble work. This balanced view is a tribute to solid research and reportage, despite Huawei’s lack of cooperation. Few of the quotes and anecdotes used from Dou’s interviews are insightful, however, giving the impression that they were included to show her authorial legwork. This is also true of an overlong account of the events following the arrest of Meng Wanzhou, Ren’s eldest daughter and at the time Huawei’s chief financial officer, by Canadian authorities in December 2018. Meng Wanzhou, eldest daughter of Huawei founder Ren, exits her vehicle after her court appearance in January 2020 in Vancouver, Canada. After a long legal saga, the U.S. dropped its fraud case against her in 2022.   © Getty Images At the request of the U.S. Justice Department, which sought her extradition to stand trial for her alleged role in misleading Huawei’s banks about its business with Iran, which contravened American sanctions. This never happened: Canada released Meng in September 2021, and she returned to a hero’s welcome in China. The case was dropped by the U.S. in 2022. The tale of Meng’s trials and tribulations fizzles out anticlimactically at the end of “House of Huawei,” and it is a shame that Dou does not offer deeper insights about what the history of the episode means for the company’s future. But it does illustrate the lengths to which the U.S. has gone to isolate Huawei internationally, which have also included barring it from selling 5G and other network gear in the U.S., and convincing allies to do likewise. As Dou carefully documents, the underpinning rationale for the ongoing U.S. attempts to isolate Huawei was not based on clear evidence that the company was helping Chinese spymasters, but rather on the knowledge that U.S. companies were doing so for their own government. Dou’s failure to provide smoking guns may disappoint some, but “House of Huawei” does provide a clear picture of the forces that have underpinned and driven Huawei for decades. It is a rare and vital account of one of the world’s most influential global technology companies — which just happens to operate, as Dou concludes, in a way that is “strikingly similar to how the nation operates as a whole.” That fact is integral to its survival. The book does not shy away from Huawei’s provable bad deeds, from supplying surveillance gear to the Chinese government for use in Xinjiang province to building so-called smart cities for despotic regimes in Africa and the Middle East. But it is careful to portray Huawei as a technology company that operates like the Chinese state, not for it. That is a distinction the rest of the world should also make. “House of Huawei: The Secret History of China’s Most Powerful Company” by Eva Dou (Penguin Random House, 2025) Ross O’Brien is a contributing writer. He has previously acted as a consultant to Huawei.

title: Tokyo Gas takes step back from growth-over-returns approach
description: Tokyo Gas had cut back on its previously high shareholder returns to fund long-term growth investments. (Photo by Kosuke Imamura) Utility readies $800m buyback as battery, shale gas investments raise profit concerns SHINO KATAYAMA March 27, 2025 07:05 JST TOKYO — Tokyo Gas will repurchase up to 120 billion yen ($800 million) in stock during the first half of fiscal 2025, the utility said Wednesday, in a shift back toward shareholder returns as major growth investments have struggled to bear fruit. The full amount would match the record 120 billion yen in buybacks the Japanese utility conducted in all of fiscal 2024, and do so in half the time. Tokyo Gas said it will consider further buybacks in the second half “based on company performance,” and raised its annual dividend for fiscal 2024 by 10 yen per share to 80 yen. “Though long-term growth is important to us, we cannot meet stakeholders’ expectations unless we focus to some extent on short-term economics,” President Shinichi Sasayama said in a briefing, adding that the company will “sincerely face” skepticism about its ability to achieve its fiscal 2025 target of 8% return on equity. A disclosure released last fall showed Elliott Investment Management owned more than 5% of Tokyo Gas. The activist investor has been pressuring the company to sell assets and return money to shareholders, a source familiar with the situation said. Once known for its high returns for shareholders, Tokyo Gas changed tack over the past few years, with Sasayama saying “we want to give back to shareholders through sustainable growth.” In fiscal 2020, the utility changed its shareholder payout ratio policy, lowering the target from around 60% to roughly 40% by fiscal 2023. Meanwhile, the company has outlined plans to spend 650 billion yen on growth investments in the three years through fiscal 2025, up from 475.8 billion yen in the preceding three years. During this pivot, Tokyo Gas invested in areas such as storage batteries and North American shale gas development, but has yet to see notable successes. Its return on assets, based on adjusted ordinary profit, came to 4.2% last fiscal year, 3.8 percentage points lower than in fiscal 2012. “Investment in fossil fuels makes money in the short term, but there’s a lot of uncertainty over the medium to long term,” an analyst said. “Investments in renewable energy and decarbonization are likely to become profitable in the medium to long term, but don’t make money now — they’re tough.” Tokyo Gas has pared its shareholder returns to keep funding investments with a long time horizon. Its domestic city gas business, which generates steady profits, has become a smaller part of the portfolio. S&P Global Ratings in November downgraded its outlook on the company’s long-term bonds from “stable” to “negative,” citing concerns about the possible impact of that shift on earnings and cash flow. Tokyo Gas is considering ways to boost profit while limiting outlays, such as acquiring usage rights to power generation and storage facilities owned by other companies. The utility plans to boost return on assets by divesting at least 100 billion yen in assets between fiscal 2025 and fiscal 2028.

title: Trump announces additional 25% tariff on foreign-made autos
description: U.S. President Donald Trump said auto tariffs will go into effect on April 2 and be on all countries. © Reuters White House expects over $100 billion in new annual revenues KEN MORIYASU March 27, 2025 06:46 JST WASHINGTON — U.S. President Donald Trump signed a proclamation imposing a 25% tariff on foreign-made cars and light trucks on Wednesday, in a move that the White House says will result in over $100 billion of new annual revenues. The tariffs will be charged in addition to ones that are already in place. The U.S. currently levies 2.5% on passenger vehicles and 25% on pickup trucks. “I think our automobile business will flourish like it’s never flourished before,” the president said, as he signed the order in the Oval Office. Trump said the auto tariffs will go into effect next Wednesday and apply to all countries. He added that auto parts that cross borders through the manufacturing process will not be subject to tariffs, but that such transactions will go down in the future. “For the most part, I think it’s going to lead cars to be made in one location,” he said. “Right now, a car would be made here, sent to Canada, sent to Mexico, sent all over the place. It’s ridiculous.”

title: Japan pension whale GPIF’s new chief brings bank expertise
description: Uchida will become the first GPIF head to hail from one of Japan's top banks. (Source photos by Nikkei) Kazuto Uchida has experience managing funds, working overseas Nikkei staff writers March 27, 2025 05:33 JST TOKYO — Japan’s Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) will have a bank veteran with extensive experience on the front line of fund management as its new chief next month. Former Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group Director Kazuto Uchida will assume the top post at GPIF on April 1. “He has ample specialized knowledge and experience,” said Minister of Health, Labor and Welfare Takamaro Fukuoka at a Tuesday press conference announcing the appointment. Uchida will be the first GPIF head to hail from one of Japan’s top banks since the fund was established in 2006.
