GPIF, one of the world’s largest institutional investors, manages premiums paid to the country’s National Pension and Employees’ Pension Insurance system, with managed assets reaching 258 trillion yen ($1.71 trillion) at the end of 2024. It is often called a “whale” due to its investments’ sway on the market.  Uchida joined Mitsubishi Bank — now MUFG Bank — in 1985 and has long been involved in fund management. He was head of the section responsible for investing in yen assets, mainly Japanese government bonds. He also served as head of the market department, overseeing fund investment both at home and overseas for two years. He also served as chairman of Mitsubishi UFJ Morgan Stanley Securities. “He provides balanced and neutral analysis of the market and the economy in general,” said Nomura Research Institute’s executive economist Takahide Kiuchi, who knows Uchida well. “He is knowledgeable about banking in general and has management experience.” SMBC Nikko Securities analyst Hidenori Suezawa noted that Uchida “has an international background, having worked in the U.S.” He is expected to tackle two goals: securing investment returns and strengthening the organization. GPIF’s investment returns have been strong, with assets under management increasing 50% in the five years from the end of 2019 to the end of 2024. Success in pension asset management is judged by the effective yield — the difference between the rate of returns and the pace of nominal wage increases. GPIF’s stated target is 1.7%, with its actual results from fiscal 2001 to fiscal 2023 averaging 4.24% per year. The welfare ministry will raise the effective yield target to 1.9% from fiscal 2025. Many companies have announced wage increases, and nominal wage growth is expected to accelerate. As Japanese interest rates rise above zero amid inflation, GPIF is expected to produce higher returns. Securing workers is also an issue. As assets under management increase, the skills required for investment and risk management also become more advanced.

title: Asia needs to ensure power grids are in step with renewables growth
description: Technicians work to install a high voltage electric transmission line at the substation of Gujarat Solar Park in Gujarat, India on Sept, 12, 2024. © Reuters Upgrades are needed to unlock the full potential of wind and solar power projects Vandana Hari Vandana Hari March 27, 2025 05:05 JST Vandana Hari is founder of Vanda Insights, a Singapore-based global energy market intelligence provider. The recent boom in wind and solar power generation capacity has been hailed as a promising low-carbon solution to the world’s growing demand for energy, with governments doubling down on renewables as part of their net-zero emission targets. But a gaping hole has opened up in the execution of this strategy. Electricity grids around the world are struggling to integrate new solar and wind power projects — and the continued rapid growth in the latter will only make the situation worse. About 1,650 gigawatts of wind and solar projects in advanced stages of development around the world were waiting for grid connections as of July 2024, the International Energy Agency said in a February report. To put that in context, that figure is equivalent to around 52% of the current wind and solar capacity installed across the globe. Major developing economies in Asia are especially vulnerable to the downside of the growing disconnect between renewable power generation capacity and grid capacity due to multiple factors: A relatively high rate of urbanization spurring strong demand growth for power; the need for affordable, stable and accessible universal supply; rapidly growing reliance on oil and gas imports; and grid systems that are mostly government dominated. Investment in power transmission — the network of high-voltage power lines, substations, transformers and other infrastructure that moves electricity from power plants to the distribution networks that reach the final consumers — is woefully inadequate around the world, according to the IEA, but especially faces major funding gaps in developing economies. Countries looking to expand and upgrade their grids are also facing steep price hikes and long waits to get the critical components. On the supply side, there are limited equipment manufacturers globally, who in turn are struggling with supply chain bottlenecks, cost escalations and a shortage of skilled labor, leading to massive backlogs. Lead times for power transformers have doubled to four years and prices have rocketed 75% since 2019, while the waiting time for high-voltage cables has risen to three years and prices have nearly doubled since 2019, the IEA found. Grid integration is challenging for wind and solar projects because they are typically located in remote or rural areas, selected on the basis of access to land and sunlight or strong wind flows. As a result, they need the setting up of long-distance transmission networks — with the added complexity of underwater sea cables in the case of offshore wind — to deliver electricity to the grid. In contrast, coal- or gas-fired power plants are typically built near consumption centers, making them relatively easier to connect with existing high-voltage transmission networks. Intermittency in wind and solar projects — the loss of power output when the wind doesn’t blow and the sun doesn’t shine — needs balancing mechanisms such as battery storage or pumped hydro, and “smart grid” systems that can allow grid operators to anticipate and manage the fluctuations, all of which also needs considerable investment. China has built an industry to produce the full array of transmission and distribution system components but is using much of its manufacturing capacity to serve galloping domestic demand, according to the Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis. China added about 277 GW of new solar capacity in 2024, a 45% jump from 2023, and 80 GW of wind capacity for an increase of 18%. Southeast Asian countries, endowed with rich wind and solar power resources, need to avoid the trap of pursuing only one part of the renewables build-out equation while increasing their import dependency on an already stretched grid components sector. Workers install solar panels on Tseng Tien-fu’s vanilla farm in Taoyuan, Taiwan on May 30, 2022.   © Reuters As the IEEFA puts it, solar panels and wind turbines are “the most identifiable symbols of the energy transition,” and Southeast Asian governments have encouraged and even mandated local production of these components. At the same time, downstream policy incentives have stimulated fund inflows into construction of wind and solar power plants. But the electricity grid appears to have been neglected. Governments in the region need to heed growing calls from prominent energy policy and research organizations to create fully grid-integrated supply projects and localize grid equipment supply chains. “Investment in transmission equipment production could be pivotal in ensuring energy security, reliability and availability,” according to the IEEFA. The International Renewable Energy Agency has urged Southeast Asian countries to invest in modernizing and expanding grid infrastructure, with a focus on adopting advanced technologies for grid flexibility and energy storage systems needed to accommodate the growing share of wind and solar power generation. In most countries in the region — with the exception of the Philippines — state-owned enterprises control power transmission and often also have a monopoly or dominant role in power generation and distribution, with governments regulating electricity tariffs. Policymakers need to quickly figure out ways to manage the dichotomy between power grids as a legacy state-owned and state-managed part of the electricity ecosystem and the demands of private sector-led, fast-growing wind and solar generation. Whether it is done through state funding or with the help of private investment, the expansion, upgradation and modernization of power grids through digitalization needs to be prioritized. On the flip side, not doing so in time may spur an irreversible exodus of investors from wind and solar projects. Policymakers need to find ways to catalyze local manufacturing of power grid components. It could be done at a national level, or through overseas joint ventures with existing players and financing from multilateral development banks. A good starting point would be to bring the boring but critical backbone of power grids to the fore in policymaking and industry discussions, regionally and internationally. While renewables and other forms of “green” power generation have become common on the agenda of oil and gas conferences in recent years, the grid has remained in the shadows. It’s encouraging to see the second-ever edition of the Astana International Forum in Kazakhstan, planned for May 29 and 30, which aims at finding solutions to the challenges of climate change, food shortages and energy security, dedicating a session exclusively to nations ensuring power supply stability amid the intermittency of renewables and supply chain issues. More conferences and seminars focused on the entire power sector ecosystem from generation to distribution are needed to facilitate the exchange of know-how and spur collaboration opportunities among industry players, policymakers, investors and think tanks. This has become critical if we are to prevent the wind and solar power bandwagon from decoupling and derailing.

title: Japan’s Tokio Marine Asset exits net-zero alliance after BlackRock
description: Industry-based alliances working toward reaching net-zero emissions face headwinds as the Trump administration rolls back climate initiatives. © Reuters Industry climate initiative loses steam amid Trump rollbacks OKI HIDAKA and HARUKI KITAGAWA March 27, 2025 05:00 JST TOKYO — Tokio Marine Asset Management left an environmentally focused investor group at the end of February, Nikkei has learned, marking the first exit by a major Japanese player amid growing headwinds on global efforts to combat climate change. Tokio Marine Asset said it made the decision after reviewing the purpose of its membership, including whether participation in the Net Zero Asset Managers (NZAM) initiative was helping solve societal challenges. Tokio Marine Asset said it will not abandon contributions toward a creating decarbonized society. Other major Japanese asset managers, including Nomura Asset Management, Daiwa Asset Management and Mitsubishi UFJ Asset Management, remained part of NZAM as of Wednesday. Sompo Asset Management, which like Tokio Marine Asset is a subsidiary of a nonlife insurance group, is still also part of the framework. Overseas, U.S.-based BlackRock, the world’s biggest asset manager, exited NZAM in January, saying its membership “caused confusion regarding BlackRock’s practices and subjected us to legal inquiries from various public officials.” BlackRock has played a leading role in the sector’s efforts to address climate change risks. But Republican lawmakers have accused it of forcing green strategies on U.S. businesses. With U.S. President Donald Trump rolling back climate-related initiatives, BlackRock may be wary of drawing further criticism or losing business opportunities. Following BlackRock’s departure, NZAM said it would suspend activities while it reviews objectives and operations. It has also taken down its roster from the website. “Unless NZAM settles on its direction, we can’t decide on how we will respond as a company,” said an executive at a leading asset manager. Whether other Japanese players will follow Tokio Marine Asset remains to be seen. “We know there have been some departures overseas, but we can’t make the decision on our own since we manage assets belonging to other owners,” an industry insider said. “Depending on the situation, we may need to consider an exit,” said the head of one asset manager. In related fields, all three leading Japanese insurance groups, including Tokio Marine Asset’s parent, Tokio Marine Holdings, have exited the United Nations-backed Net-Zero Insurance Alliance. Six U.S. banks, including Goldman Sachs and Wells Fargo, as well as major Japanese players like Sumitomo Mitsui Banking , have left the Net-Zero Banking Alliance, another U.N.-backed group, since December.

title: Tesla to launch in Saudi Arabia as Musk and the kingdom mend relations
description: Tesla sells in other Middle Eastern countries, but not in Saudi Arabia. © Reuters Sales start in April, five years after feud with PIF over taking automaker private March 27, 2025 04:11 JST RIYADH (Reuters) — Tesla will start sales in Saudi Arabia next month, the electric carmaker said on its website, signaling CEO Elon Musk and the kingdom have healed a rift that dates back to the billionaire’s short-lived bid in 2018 to take the company private. Tesla sells in other Middle Eastern countries, but not in Saudi Arabia, the Gulf region’s largest market, where EVs only account for 1% of total car sales. The brand has had considerable success in neighboring United Arab Emirates, where most ride-hailing apps offer electric vehicles. The dispute started when Musk tweeted in 2018 he had “funding secured” to take Tesla private after a meeting with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, the Public Investment Fund. That tweet eventually led to a lawsuit from investors when a bid failed to materialize, during which tense text messages between Musk and PIF head Yasir al-Rumayyan were made public. Tensions have eased since the autumn, when Musk took a high-profile role in U.S. President Donald Trump’s election campaign and then new administration. Trump said this month he would likely make his first trip abroad to Saudi Arabia, after asking the kingdom in January to spend upward of $1 trillion in the U.S. economy over four years, including military purchases. EVs from China’s BYD and PIF-backed Lucid are already available in the Saudi market. EV sales have been slow in Saudi Arabia, with a 2024 report from consultants PwC putting them at just 1% of all car sales. Tesla’s launch event in Riyadh, scheduled for April 10, will display its EVs and products powered by solar energy, the post said. “Experience the future of autonomous driving with Cybercab, and meet Optimus, our humanoid robot, as we showcase what’s next in AI and robotics,” it added. On April 11, it will open pop-up stores in Riyadh, Jeddah and Dammam, Tesla said in a later statement, adding it would announce further details of its plans for Saudi Arabia in the coming weeks, with investment planned for 2025 and beyond. Invitations to the launch event asked guests to indicate which Tesla car model they were interested in. A month after the feud with Musk went public, the PIF announced a $1-billion-plus investment in Lucid, becoming the majority investor in one of the EV startups looking to challenge Tesla. PIF, which has assets under management of $925 billion, has also invested in a domestic EV brand that is yet to launch called Ceer. Yet large, gas-guzzling vehicles remain the norm on Saudi roads where fuel is cheap and EV charging infrastructure remains a rarity, making traversing its long desert roads almost impossible in an EV. The launch comes as Tesla has seen EV sales slump in Europe, blamed on Musk’s support for far right politicians, and the brand has been targeted by protesters in the United States over his spearheading of sweeping cuts to the federal government. In one of the first signs of improving relations, Musk appeared alongside Rumayyan and Trump in ringside seats at a UFC mixed martial arts match in New York in November. A few weeks earlier, Musk had made a surprise appearance at Riyadh’s Future Investment Initiative summit via video link. A U.S. jury found in 2023 that Musk was not liable for misleading investors when he tweeted funding was secured to take Tesla private. Musk testified it was the PIF that had wanted to take Tesla private when he posted that tweet, and a series of tense text messages between him and Rumayyan emerged during the case. “You are throwing me under the bus,” Musk wrote in a text to Rumayyan, according to court documents. Tesla’s sales in Europe are down 42.6% so far this year, data showed on Tuesday, even as demand for EVs rises. Activists across the U.S. have staged “Tesla Takedown” demonstrations over Musk’s role leading the Department of Government Efficiency, which has cut thousands of jobs, frozen foreign aid and canceled thousands of programs and contracts.

title: Analysis: Panama port deal puts ‘prophet’ Li Ka-shing to the test
description: Li Ka-shing might look like he is caught in the middle of a Donald Trump-Xi Jinping feud, but history shows he has a knack for maneuvering around politics and ahead of economic trends. (Nikkei montage/Source photos by Reuters and Yusuke Hinata) The Hong Kong tycoon's move comes as the U.S. and China ratchet up tensions KATSUJI NAKAZAWA KATSUJI NAKAZAWA March 27, 2025 04:00 JST Katsuji Nakazawa is a Tokyo-based senior staff and editorial writer at Nikkei. He spent seven years in China as a correspondent and later as China bureau chief. He was the 2014 recipient of the Vaughn-Ueda International Journalist prize. CK Hutchison founder Li Ka-shing has made his way back into the global spotlight by deciding to sell the rights to operate ports on either side of the Panama Canal, which has become a pain point in U.S.-China tensions. While the Hong Kong tycoon’s move might win him points in Washington, it has put him in Beijing’s crosshairs. But Li might not even feel the pressure. The 96-year-old billionaire has a well-established reputation for his ability to see what is likely to happen in the future and to take appropriate action. He is known to have correctly predicted a dramatic change in the Chinese real estate market and sold off many mainland assets before the country’s property bubble started to collapse in 2021. So has the man who has witnessed decades of fierce power struggles within the Chinese Communist Party made another prediction, one about U.S.-China relations? Li Ka-shing made inroads into China in the first half of the 1990s by deepening relationships with companies affiliated with the Ministry of Transport.   © Reuters Exactly 30 years ago, Li learned firsthand the dark side of Chinese politics through his involvement in a huge development project in Wangfujing, a busy shopping district in central Beijing. Wangfujing is not far from Zhongnanhai, the country’s political nerve center where party leaders have their offices. On April 4, 1995, gunfire rang out in a suburb of Beijing, and Wang Baosen, Beijing’s then-most senior vice mayor, was found dead. It is said he committed suicide by shooting himself in the head. Wang’s shocking death developed into a major corruption scandal that rocked Chinese politics. Shortly afterward, Chen Xitong, who was Beijing’s top official and a key member of the “Beijing faction,” was purged for corruption. Chen, who was a member of the party’s powerful Politburo, was eventually sentenced to 16 years in prison, and questions were later raised about whether his corruption charge had more to do with a serious crime. After the deadly Tiananmen Square crackdown on pro-democracy students in 1989, Jiang Zemin, then Shanghai’s top official, was suddenly tapped as the party’s general secretary. Jiang replaced Zhao Ziyang, who was purged in the wake of Tiananmen Square for showing a sympathetic attitude toward the protesting students. Jiang was “a new face” in Beijing. Although he had the backing of then-supreme leader Deng Xiaoping, his own political base was extremely weak. Jiang Zemin and Li Peng join a news conference at The Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Sept. 26, 1989. Jiang became the party’s general secretary that year.   © Reuters In essence, Chen’s downfall was the result of a dog-eat-dog power struggle within the party. Jiang, who led the “Shanghai faction,” drove Chen out to consolidate his power as the influential Beijing faction member had stood in his way. Chen’s corruption case involved Li’s massive development project in Wangfujing. Li must have felt his blood freeze as he was seen as being at the center of the case. But the case — in essence an outgrowth of a party power struggle — only impacted the Hong Kong tycoon temporarily. Li made inroads into China in the first half of the 1990s, after Tiananmen Square sparked harsh Western sanctions. He deepened his relationships with companies affiliated with the Ministry of Transport, including in the port and terminal business. Around the time of the 1995 corruption scandal involving Chen, Li began to forge an even closer relationship with Jiang, who won his power struggle and cemented his position as successor to the aged Deng. Connections to Jiang and those close to him who controlled China’s transport-related sectors were a tremendous asset for Li. They paved the way for China to support one of CK Hutchison’s subsidiaries to acquire the rights to operate the two Panama ports. Li was indebted to Deng and Jiang for helping his business expand in China and beyond. U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio tours the Miraflores locks at the Panama Canal in Panama City on Feb. 2. After the U.S. made the canal a point of contention between itself and China, Panama announced it would withdraw from the China-led Belt and Road Initiative in 2026. (Pool photo/Reuters) The CK Hutchison subsidiary acquired the rights from the Panamanian government in 1997. The handover of Hong Kong from the U.K. to China also took place that year. The ports in question are the port of Balboa on the Pacific side of the canal and the port of Cristobal on the Atlantic side. In 2021, four years after the U.K. handed over Hong Kong, China joined the World Trade Organization under Jiang, and U.S.-China trade quickly expanded. As a result, CK Hutchison’s profits from operating the Panama ports grew. This trend accelerated during the era of Jiang’s successor, Hu Jintao, as the Chinese economy grew rapidly. But China, its economy and the world it exists in have drastically changed since Xi Jinping took over from Hu as party general secretary in 2012. The change in U.S.-China relations has been especially dramatic. When Donald Trump, who in January was inaugurated for a second term as U.S. president, declared he would take back the Panama Canal, CK Hutchison faced the possibility of becoming a direct target. Despite Trump’s threat coming suddenly, it was not long before Panama announced it would withdraw from the China-led Belt and Road Initiative in 2026, when its memorandum of understanding with China to cooperate on the global infrastructure drive is due to expire. With Panama more or less bowing to Trump, suddenly the threat to CK Hutchison became all the more real. Li moved quickly. On March 4, his conglomerate signed an agreement to sell its non-Chinese port assets, including the two Panama Canal ports, to a consortium led by U.S. asset management firm BlackRock. An unhappy Xi administration responded to the announced deal, albeit indirectly, after the National People’s Congress, China’s national legislature, ended its annual session on March 11. The Hong Kong and Macao Work Office of the party’s Central Committee reposted on its website a harshly critical article published in Ta Kung Pao, a Chinese government-affiliated Hong Kong newspaper. This commentary published by Ta Kung Pao suggests it is “understandable” that many would view the Panama deal as a betrayal of the Chinese people. (Photo by Kenji Kawase) The article lashed out at the deal, claiming it would undermine China’s national security and interests. Ta Kung Pao also published a commentary calling for CK Hutchison to halt the transaction and suggesting the deal would violate the national security ordinance, which took effect in Hong Kong a year ago. It remains unclear whether Beijing’s indirect pressure could lead to CK Hutchison reconsidering its decision. CK Hutchison is a private company, not state-owned. The conglomerate is huge but does not have the power to shrug off the political risk that comes from being caught between the world’s two largest economic foes. Although the Xi administration often stresses the need for “patriotism” and “national security,” there is no way it could protect CK Hutchison from the pressure that would be piled onto it by a determined U.S. Three decades ago, with the handover looming, Hong Kong companies began moving closer to mainland China under a “one country, two systems” formula that promised “a high degree of autonomy” for the former British colony. Deng firmly pledged to keep the formula unchanged for 50 years after the handover. Jiang and Hu maintained the guarantee, which has since disintegrated. In the new political reality, it is only natural for Hong Kong merchants to behave differently. Li was born in China’s Guangdong province, adjacent to Hong Kong, in 1928. His long life has allowed him to observe many chapters of Chinese history. The lessons he has taken away have taught him how to be quick to seize an opportunity. Li Ka-shing, chairman of CK Hutchison Holdings, waves goodbye to journalists as he formally retires after the company’s annual general meeting in Hong Kong on May 10, 2018. Li would burnish his reputation as “a prophet” some three years later.   © Reuters He has also gained the ability to correctly predict where China’s economy and politics — and the international political and economic situations surrounding China — are headed. He demonstrated his foresight by gradually selling off many of his mainland property holdings after Xi became China’s top leader. Prominent Chinese real estate moguls were paying attention to the Hong Kong billionaire’s low-profile asset sell-off, and some of them also escaped the implosion unscathed by following Li’s example. As a result, Li’s reputation as “a prophet” became rock-solid. This time, Li has decided to divest CK Hutchison’s operating rights for many overseas ports even as they generate profits. Will this also prove prescient?

title: Major Japan regional bank seeks stake in peer as interest rates rise
description: Japan's banks are rushing to bolster their foundations with the country's interest rates finally rising. (Photo by Yutaka Miyaguchi) Chiba Bank would become Chiba Kogyo's top shareholder in $130mn deal RYUTA MINAMIHATA March 27, 2025 00:08 JST TOKYO — Japanese regional lender Chiba Bank is finalizing plans to acquire a nearly 20% stake in peer Chiba Kogyo Bank for an estimated 20 billion yen ($133 million), Nikkei has learned, looking to bolster its foundation as interest rates rise. Chiba Bank, the largest regional bank in Chiba prefecture, just east of Tokyo, will purchase the shares from Ariake Capital, an investment company that targets regional lenders and other entities. Under the share transfer agreement expected soon, Chiba Bank will acquire 19.9% of the shares in Chiba Kogyo, the prefecture’s third largest regional bank, on a voting rights basis. Ariake Capital began making substantial investments in Chiba Kogyo around 2022, providing advice on improving management. It became the largest shareholder in January 2025. Chiba Kogyo’s market capitalization stands around 90 billion yen, making the stake to be acquired by Chiba Bank worth about 18 billion yen. Chiba Bank is expected to become the largest shareholder. Several large regional banks have been able to coexist in Chiba, given the prefecture’s large population and numerous companies stemming from its location in the greater Tokyo metro area. But population decline in southern Chiba has led to consolidation of some branches. With the Bank of Japan moving last year to reverse its longtime negative interest rate policy, and with further rate hikes on the horizon, banks are rushing to solidify their foundations in order to acquire deposits and support business partners. Chiba Kogyo was established in 1952. When Japan’s economic bubble burst, the bank was left with many bad loans and received public funds in 2000. Even after paying off its debt, the lender had to deal with the redemption of preferred shares, which carried a heavy dividend burden. Japan’s Financial Services Agency requires companies that acquire a 20% stake or more of banks and other institutions to obtain authorization for such reasons as ensuring management stability. Chiba Bank and Chiba Kogyo will discuss their future structure and cooperative relationship. Chiba Bank appears to be considering acquiring more than 20% to strengthen the relationship further. As the two banks deepen their relationship, the response of major Japanese lender Mizuho Bank, which holds 12.6% of Chiba Kogyo’s shares, also will be a focus. Mizuho’s predecessor, the former Fuji Bank, took on Chiba Kogyo’s capital increases. Mizuho counted Chiba Kogyo as an equity method affiliate for many years, until 2023.

description: A new AI model has been developed that can quickly tell how much weeds have grown—and it could help ensure global food security by accelerating the development of next-generation herbicides.

title: Polymerlike worms wriggle their way through mazes
description: In a crowded room, we naturally move slower than in an empty space. Surprisingly, worms can show the exact opposite behavior: In an environment with randomly scattered obstacles, they tend to move faster when there are more obstructions. Viewing the worms as "active, polymerlike matter," researchers at the University of Amsterdam have now explained this surprising fact.

title: New discovery promises to reveal hidden black holes across the universe
description: Scientists have detected radio signals from hot gas surrounding a supermassive black hole that existed 12.9 billion years ago, according to new research published in Nature Astronomy from an international team of scientists including researchers from The Australian National University (ANU).

title: Unlocking rice's yield potential: Trio of genes holds the key, study shows
description: A research team led by Dr. Li Yunhai from the Institute of Genetics and Developmental Biology of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) has uncovered a novel genetic mechanism that controls grain size and yield in rice, offering promising strategies to enhance global food production.

title: Fighting bacteria with viruses: Important step to treating antibiotic-resistant infections
description: New insights into a "friendly virus" that could pave the way for cutting-edge treatments for the potentially fatal superbug C. diff have been uncovered by University of Sheffield scientists.

title: Transistor reshapes electronic properties of a 2D material
description: A RIKEN study shows that squeezing the right amount of potassium ions between the atomic layers of molybdenum disulfide can turn it from a semiconductor into a metal, superconductor or insulator. The same layered material can be made to behave as a superconductor, metal, semiconductor or insulator by using a transistor device developed by RIKEN physicists to tweak its electronic properties.

title: Physicists discover a copper-free high-temperature superconducting oxide
description: Professor Ariando and Dr. Stephen Lin Er Chow from the National University of Singapore (NUS) Department of Physics have designed and synthesized a groundbreaking new material—a copper-free superconducting oxide—capable of superconducting at approximately 40 Kelvin (K), or about minus 233°C, under ambient pressure.

title: Even the common people drank wine in Troy
description: For the first time ever, a team of researchers has found chemical evidence that wine was actually drunk in Troy, verifying a conjecture of Heinrich Schliemann, who discovered the legendary fortress city in the 19th century. In addition, the researchers from the Universities of Tübingen, Bonn and Jena found that not only members of the Trojan elite but the common people too drank wine. Their findings are now being published in the April edition of the American Journal of Archaeology.

title: Small star, mighty flares: ALMA shares new view of Proxima Centauri
description: At a distance of just over four light years, Proxima Centauri is our nearest stellar neighbor and is known to be a very active M dwarf star. Its flare activity has been well-known to astronomers using visible wavelengths of light, but a new study using observations with the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) array highlights this star's extreme activity in radio and millimeter wavelengths, offering exciting insights about the particle nature of these flares as well as potential impacts to the livability of its terrestrial, habitable-zone planets.

title: Atmospheres of new planets might have unexpected mixtures of hydrogen and water
description: All planets are made of gas, ice, rock and metal, and models of how planets form usually assume that these materials don't react chemically with each other. But what if some of them do?

title: Psychological implications and best practices for virtual communication in modern workflows
description: Despite the growth and popularity of remote work, companies and governments have increasingly been calling their employees back to the office in the past year, sometimes at the expense of significant declines in employee satisfaction. Return-to-office mandates are often based on the belief that in-person work leads to greater productivity and better relationship-building and creativity than virtual collaboration can offer. But is this true?

title: Four new gamma-ray millisecond pulsars discovered
description: An international team of astronomers reports the detection of four new gamma-ray millisecond pulsars using the Murriyang radio telescope at the Parkes Observatory in Australia. The discovery was detailed in a research paper published March 16 on the arXiv preprint server.

title: Fire fighting helicopter tackles Thailand blazes
description: A bright orange helicopter races over the jungle to dump water on a raging wildfire that is adding to the air pollution choking Thailand's northern tourist hub of Chiang Mai.

title: Colorado's wolves expand their territory
description: Colorado's collared gray wolves continue to roam the state's northwest corner and central mountains as wildlife officials wait and watch for signs new pups might be born this spring.

title: Physics meets art: A new twist on interference patterns
description: One of the simplest and most beautiful naturally occurring patterns can be observed when light is shined through a pair of slightly misaligned periodic structures. This phenomenon, known as the moiré effect, is not only pretty to look at, but also has important consequences for the properties of materials.

title: Earth 1, asteroids 0: The next generation of planetary defense takes shape at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory
description: There is a non-zero chance that somewhere in the nearby solar system is a rock that might kill us all.

title: Study uncovers origin of the large neutron-capture cross section in ⁸⁸Zr using new methodology
description: Studies that explore how the denser sections of atoms, known as atomic nuclei, interact with neutrons (i.e., particles with no electric charge) can have valuable implications both for the understanding of these atoms' underlying physics and for the development of nuclear energy solutions. A process that is central to these interactions is neutron capture, which entails the absorption of a neutron by a nucleus, followed by the emission of gamma-rays.

title: Damaging cluster of UK winter storms driven by swirling polar vortex miles above Earth, scientists say
description: Powerful winter storms which led to deaths and power outages in the UK and Ireland were made more likely by an intense swirling vortex of winds miles above the Arctic, say scientists.

title: DNA microscope creates 3D images of organisms from the inside out
description: Standard genetic sequencing approaches can tell you a lot about the genetic makeup and activity in a sample, like a piece of tissue or drop of blood. But they don't tell you where specific genetic sequences were located inside that sample, or their relationship to other genes and molecules.

title: Amber Glenn, the skater redefining what power looks like on the ice
description: She’s a Grand Prix champion, a triple Axel pioneer and one of figure skating’s most formidable athletes. But her artistry, not just her athleticism, may be what changes the sport When Amber Glenn takes the ice for the free skate on Friday night at the world figure skating championships in Boston after a disappointing short program , fans will be holding their breath. Undefeated this season, she was seen as the one to beat. The Grand Prix final Champion , two-time US champion , the only woman to regularly land a triple Axel in competition (on which she suffered an uncharacteristic fall, landing her ninth place in the short on Wednesday afternoon), she had been tipped to become the first US woman to win the world title in nearly 20 years. But with less than seven points between her and first place, nothing is impossible. And while much of the tenacity that could still bring her victory this week lies in her raw athleticism, Glenn has something in her arsenal more tenuous, and more volatile: She’s an artist. At first glance, Glenn doesn’t appear so different to the all-American skating stars of past decades. Slender, with blonde curled hair framing her perfectly made up face, she doesn’t overtly break the mold. But when the music starts, something else takes over. She’s explosive; her movements deliberate, and there’s a weight to her actions that not only enables her to drive across the ice like a hockey player, but to display exquisite musicality, showcasing a sensitivity and showmanship that has gained her a devoted fanbase (and 1.5m TikTok followers ). Continue reading...

The best thing that any team can do to win the World Series is to get into the playoffs. title: Ruthless Red Bull drop rookie Lawson for Yuki Tsunoda after just two F1 races
description: Christian Horner says it is ‘purely a sporting decision’ Liam Lawson will go back to sister team RB for season Red Bull have confirmed they will replace their driver Liam Lawson with Yuki Tsunoda from their sister team, RB. Lawson has been dropped before next weekend’s Japanese Grand Prix after the New Zealander has completed just two races for the team. The decision to remove the 23-year-old, not the first time Red Bull have acted with such emphatic purpose towards an underperforming driver, was blunt even by the team’s previous standards and an indication that they demand the capability to compete for the Formula One constructors’ championship as a priority. Lawson will revert to race for RB for the rest of the season. Continue reading...

title: LeBron James discusses relationship with Michael Jordan: ‘We don’t talk’

The question of which of the players is the greatest has become such a staple of sports talkshows that it is almost a cliche. In an interview with the the Pat McAfee Show broadcast on Wednesday, James said he has little interaction with Jordan. Continue reading...

title: Emma Raducanu’s Miami Open run ends in spirited defeat to Jessica Pegula
description: Briton loses first career WTA 1000 quarter-final 6-4, 6-7 (3), 6-2 No 4 seed to face Alexandra Eala after her upset win over Iga Swiatek Emma Raducanu’s encouraging run at the Miami Open came to a difficult end in the quarter-finals on Wednesday night as she went toe-to-toe with Jessica Pegula for two and a half hours before eventually being outlasted by one of the best players in the world. After three bruising, classy sets under the lights, the fourth seed sustained her excellent level in the decisive final stages as she closed out a 6-4, 6-7 (3), 6-2 victory. Pegula will next face Alexandra Eala, who pulled off one of the great upsets in recent years earlier on Wednesday by toppling Iga Swiatek 6-2, 7-5. Eala, a 19 year-old ranked No 140 and the first Filipino player to reach the highest levels of the WTA tour, had already defeated Madison Keys, the reigning Australian Open champion, and former French Open champion Jelena Ostapenko. Continue reading...

title: The mystery and mathematics of Pelé’s disputed 1,000th goal
description: On 19 November 1969, the Brazil legend sparked wild celebrations with the 1,000th goal of his career – but it may have been scored five days earlier It was 14 November 1969. For the world’s greatest player, it wasn’t the best penalty. More an untidy scuff into the bottom corner. But it was enough for Pelé and his Santos team to open the scoring in a 3-0 friendly win over lowly Botafogo da Paraiba. More importantly, it marked the great man’s 999th senior goal. Or did it? Five days later, Santos travelled to Rio de Janeiro to face Vasco da Gama in a cup game and it seemed as if the entire nation was jammed into the cavernous Maracanã to witness a piece of football history. Despite a tropical rainstorm, every TV station, radio network and newspaper elbowed their way along the touchline waiting for the magic moment to happen. Continue reading...

title: The Joy of Six: spine-tingling sporting entrances
description: From the All Blacks to the ‘Bullet’, via boxing, basketball and more, we celebrate electrifying pre-match moments Boxing is synonymous with showpiece entrances but while fighters today utilise thrones, fireworks, mariachi bands and London buses, Chris Eubank could thrill an arena with just a tap of his gloves and a blast of Tina Turner. The preening, chiseled, British two-weight world champion thrived in front of a partisan crowd, soaking in the adoration or – usually – hatred with haughty disdain. His ring walk in Berlin before fighting Graciano Rocchigiani in 1994 is a classic of the genre , finished as ever with a vault over the top rope. Continue reading...

title: The Kings and I: Puma’s classic boots beckon me back from brief Umbro betrayal
description: I thought: new football boots, new me, but it didn’t work out … and then a special edition of my favourites came on the market There is something indescribably beautiful about finding a pair of football boots that fit you perfectly. It is like Cinderella’s glass slippers – your foot just slides in, the instep and arches ensconced in the cushioning – or putting Excalibur back in the stone. Until you go out on the pitch, anything is possible. That boot for me is the Puma King. To be clear, this isn’t an advertorial – Herr Puma hasn’t given me a brown envelope, or a free pair. They are just the boots that fit. If I had slightly narrower feet and there’s no doubt I would be in the pocket of big Copa Mundial. Continue reading...

The first transfer window will open early, and run between Sunday 1 June and Tuesday 10 June. It will then close briefly before reopening on Monday 16 June. title: Cup outsiders dream big around Europe in year of surprises
description: This season’s FA Cup has thrown up plenty of upsets, but there are more fairytales being written on the continent If you’re looking for cup magic, nowhere can match the Coupe de France in recent years. In the past three decades, Guingamp, in 2009, may be the only second-tier winners but 10 teams from outside Ligue 1 have reached the final since 2006, and five of those were from the third tier or lower. There could be another this year, with Cannes, who play in France’s regionalised fourth tier, making it to the final four. They have played eight matches to get this far without facing a top-flight side, but have dispatched three Ligue 2 teams – Grenoble, Lorient and Guingamp – at home. Continue reading...

title: ‘Getting worse’: former Afghanistan captain’s anger at state of football under Taliban rule
description: Against a backdrop of brutal Taliban rule and corruption claims, Zohib Islam Amiri sees demoralisation setting in When Zohib Islam Amiri came back to play in Afghanistan in January for the first time since 2010, he was hoping to make a difference. “I wanted to try to give some of the young Afghan kids some inspiration,” he says. “But as soon as I got there it was clear that things were even worse.” Amiri, who made his international debut as a 15-year-old in 2005 before serving as captain for more than a decade, became the first Afghanistan player to move overseas when he joined Mumbai in 2011. The defender’s return to play for Abu Muslim in the Afghanistan Champions League – a competition set up in 2021 when the Taliban regained power – was never intended to be the end of his career. But having seen his side crowned champions after a controversial 8-0 victory amid allegations of match-fixing , Amiri decided enough was enough. Continue reading...

title: Mika Biereth: the Londoner who keeps scoring hat-tricks in Ligue 1
description: The Denmark striker – who played for the Chelsea, Fulham and Arsenal youth teams – is thriving at Monaco By Get French Football News “We understood that if we didn’t take the decision in the winter, in the summer, it would potentially be too late,” says Monaco CEO Thiago Scuro. There was a sense of “now or never” about the signing of Mika Biereth from Sturm Graz in January and, with the Danish international scoring 11 goals in his first nine Ligue 1 games, it is certainly an opportunity the club are happy they seized. That “now or never” feeling characterises Biereth’s whole career. “He had the bravery to go to Scotland, then Austria and now France and that is what shows he wants to be the best. He has to be playing to prove that,” says his mentor, Ian Wright. Biereth has grasped every chance he has been given along a path that has led him away from Arsenal and into Monaco’s grateful arms. Continue reading...

title: Football Association drops plans for women’s football pyramid expansion
description: Plan would have meant WSL B teams in lower leagues Extensive consultation receives widespread praise The Football Association has decided not to press ahead with a proposal to expand tiers three to six of the English women’s football pyramid that would have led to B teams from Women’s Super League teams introduced into the lower leagues in 2026, the Guardian can reveal. The governing body sent clubs a detailed proposal in January that would have brought WSL B teams into tier four of the pyramid from as early as the 2026-27 season, and meant a major ­reconfiguration of the leagues’ promotion and rele­gation structure, but on Wednesday, all lower‑league clubs were informed that the plan will not proceed, following extensive feedback. Continue reading...

description: Brazilian followed her heart with a move across the Atlantic to the WSL in January and has already had a big impact Kerolin joined Manchester City from North Carolina Courage in January and last week showed everyone exactly why she made the move. On the biggest stage in European football, the Champions League, the Brazilian produced the performance of her City career so far to help set up a 2-0 quarter-final first leg win against Chelsea . Kerolin was a constant thorn in Chelsea’s side throughout the game and provided the assist for one of Vivianne Miedema’s two goals to set up a tantalising scoreline before the return leg at Stamford Bridge on Thursday. This is an extract from our free weekly email, Moving the Goalposts. To get the full edition, visit this page and follow the instructions . title: Chelsea fans call for investigation into Todd Boehly’s links with ticket resale website
description: Chelsea Supporters’ Trust urges Premier League to act Club co-owner is director and investor in Vivid Seats The Chelsea Supporters’ Trust has written to the Premier League chief executive, Richard Masters, calling for an investigation into the connections of the club’s co-owner Todd Boehly with the ticket exchange and resale company Vivid Seats. Boehly is a director and investor in Vivid Seats, an American site that allows users outside the UK to buy and sell tickets to concerts and sporting events, often at huge markups. British fans cannot use the site or others like it because it is illegal to resell football tickets in this way in the UK. The Premier League lists Vivid Seats as an “unauthorised ticket website”. The venues and dates for the three-Test series were confirmed on Wednesday. England will face Australia, the world champions , in Tests at ­Wembley, Everton’s new home at Bramley-Moore Dock and Leeds ­Rhinos’ Headingley on consecutive Saturdays: 25 October, 1 November and 8 November. All three games will kick-off at 2.30 and be live on the BBC. Continue reading...

title: Andy Farrell opens Lions door for son Owen and other France-based players

Farrell also said he will not pick players simply to satisfy quotas despite fears the Wales squad could be completely overlooked. On unveiling his coaching staff for the 10-game tour, Farrell revealed he and his assistants have compiled a longlist of about 75 players that includes Courtney Lawes, who is impressing for Brive in the French second division, and is likely to ­feature a number of others, including Owen Farrell. The Toulouse duo of Jack Willis and Blair Kinghorn with Kyle Sinckler, David Ribbans and Ben White, all of whom are based at ­Toulon, are also possibilities. Continue reading...

title: Wayne Gretzky was a Canadian hero. His pro-Trump rebrand is a betrayal
description: While Trump muses about annexing the US’s neighbor, the NHL star has remained quiet. My fellow Canadians are furious I remain immensely proud to have lived in Edmonton during the Oilers’ glory years, when Wayne Gretzky was not merely that city’s darling, but also a fresh-faced, flag-waving ambassador for all of Canada. On ice, he dazzled with his scoring prowess and consistency; off ice, he charmed with his various charitable deeds and aw-shucks humility. Continue reading...

title: ‘Frozen in time’: figure skating world unites in grief and tribute at Boston world championships
description: As figure skating’s world championships began in Boston , a ceremony was held in honor of the 28 members of the sport’s community who died in January’s midair collision The lights dimmed, the arena fell silent and a sport took a collective breath. On Wednesday night at TD Garden, the world figure skating championships paused between events for something far more profound than medals or scores: a solemn tribute to the 28 members of the skating community who died in January when American Eagle flight 5342 crashed into the Potomac River . Held after the women’s short program and before the start of the pairs’ short program, the ceremony honored the skaters, coaches and parents who were returning from a development camp held in conjunction with the US figure skating championships in Wichita, Kansas. Continue reading...

title: Alysa Liu vaults to shock lead at figure skating worlds with statement program
description: American leads after short at worlds as favorites falter Japan’s Chiba second, USA’s Levito third entering free Interview: Liu on her remarkable comeback to skating Alysa Liu became the youngest ever US figure skating champion at 13 years old before vanishing from the sport at 16, uncertain if she’d ever return. Now, at 19, she’s back – and suddenly within touching distance of a world title that no American woman has claimed in nearly two decades. On the opening afternoon of the world figure skating championships, the teenager from Clovis, California, delivered a career-best short program that not only captivated the home crowd at TD Garden, but vaulted her into the lead with 74.58 points – her highest international score to date. Her emotional performance to the song Promise by Laufey and Dan Wilson enamored the crowd and left Liu blinking back tears as she exited the ice. Continue reading...
